revision.text:
{{Stonyhurst College}}
The '''History of [[Stonyhurst College]]''' as a school dates back to 1593 when its antecedent, the [[College of St Omer|Jesuit College at St Omer]], was founded in [[Flanders]] to educate English Catholics. The history of the present school buildings dates as far back as 1200 AD.
==Stonyhurst Hall== {{see|Stonyhurst}}
The earliest Deed concerning the "Stanihurst" dates from 1200 AD and can now be found in the Arundell Library in the College, whilst the earliest evidence of a building on the site is from 1372 when John de Bayley was licensed to have an oratory there; the archway in the Bayley Room, within the 'Blind Tower', is believed to date from the fourteenth century, and may well be the only remnant of that earlier building.<ref>''A Stonyhurst Handbook for Visitors and Others'', third edition, 1963</ref> The oldest portion of the extant buildings however, the Shireburn Mansion (Stonyhurst Hall), was founded by the [[Roman Catholic]], Richard Shireburn, a descendant of the Bayley family, whose son attended the College at St Omers. He built the gatehouse and open cupolas (known as "the towers") on top of an older settlement dating from 1592. The design of the gatehouse incorporates four of the Classical orders (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian and Composite). Three similar designs appear on [[Merton College|Merton]] and [[Wadham College|Wadham]] Colleges and the Schools building in Oxford, though Stonyhurst's predates them all by more than a decade.<ref>''A Stonyhurst Handbook for Visitors and Others'', 3rd edition, 1963, p. 46</ref> In places the exterior walls of this part of the building are as much as six feet deep.<ref>''A Stonyhurst Handbook for Visitors and Others'', third edition, 1963, p. 46</ref>
During the Civil Wars, [[Oliver Cromwell|Oliver Cromwell's]] army encamped near the Hall on their way to the [[Battle of Preston (1648)|Battle of Preston]] in 1648. Cromwell spent the night at Stonyhurst and slept on a table in the middle of the Great Hall in full armour. He is said to have preferred this option to a bed because of fear of assassination and mistrust of his Catholic, royalist hosts.<ref>[http://www.stonyhurst.ac.uk/article_395.shtml Stonyhurst General News]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He was quoted as saying it was "the best half house" he had seen (the Hall was at that time still unfinished). <ref name="moew"> {{cite web |url=http://www.stonyhurst.ac.uk |author= Stonyhurst College |title=Quote of Cromwell |year=2007 |accessdate=2007-01-22 }}</ref>
Richard Shireburn's successor and grandson, Sir Nicholas Shireburn, began a massive building plan to extend the "half house", and completed the great hall, gardens and avenue so that it could be a great manor house. Two ponds, each measuring {{convert|660|ft|m}} by {{convert|112|ft|m}} were constructed in 1696, along with the "causeway" between, today known as the Avenue. His son Richard was poisoned in the gardens in 1702, and with no male heir Nicholas ceased building. Upon his death in 1717, the buildings passed to his wife and then to their sole heir, Mary, the Duchess of Norfolk. The Duchess was married to [[Thomas Howard, 8th Duke of Norfolk]], and lived in [[Arundel Castle]] in Sussex. Unoccupied, the buildings began to fall into disrepair. Eventually, the houses were inherited by her cousin, [[Lulworth Castle|Thomas Weld]] in 1754. Already living in Lulworth Castle, and not needing an extra house, Thomas, an old boy of St Omers, donated it to the [[Society of Jesus]], with {{convert|30|acre|m2}} of land, in 1794.
The original hall has been altered and extended over the years to become one of the largest inhabited buildings in Europe and achieving [[Grade I listed]] status from [[English Heritage]].<ref>[http://www.stonyhurst.ac.uk/article_31.shtml The College] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010115747/http://www.stonyhurst.ac.uk/article_31.shtml |date=2010-10-10 }}</ref>
The village of [[Hurst Green, Lancashire]] developed with the hall. Richard Shireburn built the village school in 1686. He also built an almshouse upon Longridge Fell, the predecessor of the Shireburn Almshouse, which his son Nicholas built c.1707. The latter was dismantled in 1946 and re-erected in the village.
<gallery> Image:Stonyhurst_quadrangle.jpg|The Front Quadrangle, exterior of the Top Refectory. Image:The Top Refectory.jpg|The Jacobean Great Hall, now known as the Top Refectory, where Cromwell spent the night. Image:Cromwell's table.jpg|The table upon which Cromwell slept. Image:Cromwell's_rock_Stonyhurst.jpg|"Cromwell's Rock" where he is said to have called the Hall "the finest half-house in England". </gallery>
==The College== ===1593-1794=== {{main|College of St Omer}}
The story of the school starts at [[Saint-Omer|St Omer]] in what was then the Spanish Low Countries in 1593, where a college was founded by Father [[Robert Parsons (Jesuit)|Robert Parsons]] for English boys, unable to receive a [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] education in [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] England. As such it was one of a number of expatriate English schools operating on the European mainland during the centuries when Catholicism was proscribed in England.
In 1762, when the French ''[[Parlement]]'' turned against the Jesuits, the school, in what was then a part of France, was forced to move. During subsequent decades, when the Jesuit Order was suppressed in most countries, the college was one of the institutions through which it managed to maintain a continuous existence.
After St Omer (still known in Stonyhurst parlance by its old English name of St. Omers), the college settled in [[Bruges]] where it continued until 1773 when it was again forced to move, reassembling at [[Liège (city)|Liège]], under the protection of its bishop.
In 1794 yet another move was forced upon the school, and a new home was found at Stonyhurst Hall in [[Lancashire]], an ideal county for the school to settle in because it was still a Catholic stronghold<ref>T. E. Muir, ''Stonyhurst'', pp. 55-61, esp. p.56: Lancashire, the "very Catholic county"</ref> and its rural, isolated character provided the hope that the school would be left alone by the authorities. Not taking any chances however, a number of hiding places were created throughout the building should the Jesuits face persecution again, and when [[Stonyhurst Saint Mary's Hall|Saint Mary's Hall]] was constructed in the following century, a secret escape tunnel, which still survives, was also built linking the seminary to an exit in the gardens. <ref name="history"> {{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14309b.htm |author=Francis Irwin (Catholic Encyclopaedia 1912) |title=Stonyhurst College |year=2003 |accessdate=2006-03-11 }}</ref>
The honour of being last student at Liege and the first at Stonyhurst was claimed by a George Lambert Clifford whose bust is today on display in the Do Room; it is recorded that he and fellow pupil from Liege, Charles Brooke were the first of the migrants to arrive at the Stonyhurst mansion and raced down the Avenue together, but whilst his antagonist was waiting to be let in, Clifford spotted an open window and darted in, to be remembered by posterity as Stonyhurst's first pupil.<ref>Hewitson, ''Stonyhurst College, Present and Past'', (Preston, 1888), pp. 32-33</ref>
<gallery> Image:Shirk_Stonyhurst.jpg|The Shirk Building. Built to accommodate the first pupils at Stonyhurst. Image:Old_Infirmary_Stonyhurst.jpg|The Old Infirmary, now home to the Jesuit community, seen from New Wing. Image:Sodality_chapel_Stonyhurst.jpg|The exterior of the Sodality Chapel, right. The New Quadrangle, left. Image:St_Peter's_Church_Stonyhurst.JPG|St Peter's Church viewed from the Old Infirmary. </gallery>
===1794–1980s=== When Clifford and his fellow pupils of [[Liège (city)|Liège]] first arrived at Stonyhurst Hall, the buildings were in an extremely bad state of disrepair, and a temporary structure was built next to the east wing to house the boys. This "temporary" building still exists, and is known as ''Shirk''.
A number of other buildings were added in the early 19th century, including the new church of St Peter's, in the Gothic style of the chapel at [[King's College, Cambridge]].
By the 1880s new building works began on the school, including removal of the ''grand stairs'' in the quad and subsequently the west wing. The temporary structures of 'Shirk' and the new west wing served the school well, but by late 19th century it needed to expand again and work was started on the south front, including the building of the Boys Chapel and the Academy Room. The south front took a considerable amount of time to build, because much of the land was swamp, resulting in the need for deeper foundations, which also created extra space. The work began in 1876 to replace the Old Playground front of 1809; the total cost of the construction (minus architect's fees) was £123,205.5s.6d. (less than the cost of refurbishing the dormitories in the same building 130 years later).<ref>''A Stonyhurst Handbook for Visitors and Others'', 3rd edition, p. 33, 1963</ref>
Stonyhurst was notable for its scientific activities, including the meteorological records of the Observatory (built in 1838). The school also prided itself on producing gentlemen philosophers: ''philosophers'' was the term used for students pursuing a course of education above secondary level at a time when Catholics were forbidden from attending Oxford or Cambridge both by English law and also by a Papal prohibition. Gas lighting was another early technological innovation at the school during this period, and the school had its own power station.
From the 1960s onwards, the Stonyhurst went through a number of changes, partly reflecting those in the Catholic Church after the [[Second Vatican Council]], but also attributable in part to the growing secular tone of British society. The number of Jesuit instructors fell steadily, reflecting the changed priorities of Catholic religious orders and the dwindling numbers of the English Jesuit province. These changes led to the closing of another Jesuit boys' public school, [[Beaumont College]], in 1966; Beaumont and Stonyhurst amalgamated. With the addition of these new pupils, Stonyhurst had to expand again and the New Wing was built beside the wing erected in the 1800s to house the Arundell Library.
The former preparatory school to [[Beaumont College]], [[St John's Beaumont]] continues to send a significant number of its leavers to Stonyhurst.
<gallery> Image:Stonyhurst_pieta.jpg|The Pieta Gallery, in the original Hall. Image:Pond from Old Infirmary.jpg|The Infirmary pond. Image:JGardens.jpg|Gardens built by Sir Nicholas Shireburn, behind the Stonyhurst Football field. Image:Shireburn_buildings_Stonyhurst.jpg|The Shireburn Quadrangle. </gallery>
===1986–2006=== After Fr Michael Bossy's fifteen-year headmastership, in 1986 the college acquired its first lay headmaster, Giles Mercer. Mercer brought in a number of changes during his time, and developed particular areas of the school. By the end of the 1980s, the school opened a new indoor swimming pool, new squash courts, a new gym and various refurbished classrooms and playrooms. Scenes from the film ''[[Three Men and a Little Lady]]'' were shot at the College.
In 1993, the school celebrated 400 years since its foundation at [[Saint-Omer]], and in 1994 200 years since its foundation at Stonyhurst Hall. Mercer set up the Centenaries appeal to raise money for new building works, including the refurbishment of the science laboratories, the Bread rooms (now English department classrooms), the language classrooms, the Ambulacrum (sports hall) and numerous other areas. The appeal also went towards building the new Centenaries Theatre. As part of the celebrations a play written by Fr William Hewett SJ was performed at the new theatre outlining the history of Stonyhurst.
Adrian Aylward succeeded Mercer in 1996, and the school continued to flourish during his ten-year leadership. In 1997, Stonyhurst began its run-up to becoming fully co-educational, and introduced girls to the preparatory school, [[Stonyhurst Saint Mary's Hall|St Mary's Hall]]. A building project was undertaken, such that by the time of Aylward's departure as headmaster refurbishment had taken place in the following areas of the school: the Old Infirmary (converted from girls' to Jesuit community accommodation), Lower Grammar, Grammar and Higher Line Playrooms, all dormitories (cubicles replaced by rooms on two storeys), the plunge (converted into dormitories and changing rooms on two storeys), the Sodality Chapel (restored), the Top Refectory, the Do Room, the Long Room, the Bayley Room, the More Library, the Syntax Wing and the shooting range. Five I.T. suites were created, CCTV was installed at all entrances, some disguised as Victorian lamp-posts, the back of the building outside the music basement was tidied up, and new landscaping and redesign of the road layout accompanied the building of the all-weather sports pitch on Harry Meadow. Classrooms were re-decorated and renamed after Saints associated with the school. At the same time, academic standards improved, with Oxbridge entry standing at around 10% in 2003. On a point of principle, Aylward withdrew Stonyhurst from academic league tables, claiming that they were of little relevance and devalued the worth of the individual.{{cn|date=February 2013}} The Stonyhurst Access Appeal was set up in 2003 to widen access to the College to those from lower-income families and to generate funds for further redevelopment. Adrian Aylward also steered the school through a difficult investigation into claims of alleged child abuse said to have taken place in the 1970s.{{cn|date=February 2013}} In 2005, after ten years, Aylward announced his resignation from June 2006. Andrew Johnson succeeded Aylward in September 2006.
===2006–Present=== As headmaster, Andrew Johnson has presided over continued alterations to the building. A new spiritual centre (the Emmaus Centre) has opened adjoining the Do Room, the Sodality Chapel has been re-dedicated, and most recently the Campion Room has been converted into a new study centre. The school has returned to the league tables as Johnson works to improve the school's academic standing. New procedures have been put in place to support and prepare Oxbridge applicants, and a new mentoring system established. Extra-curricular activities have been increased, particularly with a view to community-based work, such as the "[[Pedro Arrupe|Arrupe]] Programme"{{clarify|date=January 2018}}. Johnson also inspired the renaming of Saint Mary's Hall to [[Stonyhurst Saint Mary's Hall]], and is encouraging the prep school's doubling in size. Johnson is keen to transform Stonyhurst's academic performance as well as its standing, focusing on the quality of teaching, and moving the school towards greater academic selection.
<gallery> Image:New_Wing_Stonyhurst.jpg|New Wing, begun in 1959. Image:Cent theatre.jpg|Centenaries Theatre, St Mary's Hall, Stonyhurst, built in 1993. Image:Syntax Wing, top floor, Stonyhurst.jpg|Top floor, Syntax Wing, 2003. Image:Syntax refurbishment.jpg|Refurbishment of the second floor of Syntax Wing, 2006. </gallery>
==Local centre== [[File:St Mary's Catholic Church, Clayton-le-Moors - geograph.org.uk - 675880.jpg|thumbnail|right|St Mary's Church, Clayton-le-Moors, founded by the Jesuits from Stonyhurst]] ===Parishes=== During the 19th century, Stonyhurst was a leading Jesuit centre. In 1794, it was the only Jesuit college in the country. From Stonyhurst, the Jesuits would travel to the Catholics in the surrounding towns to say Mass. Over time, churches were built for the Catholics in those places. The Jesuit priests from Stonyhurst built St Mary's Church in [[Clayton-le-Moors]] in 1810, [[St Ignatius Church, Preston]] in 1833, [[St Stephen's Church, Skipton]] in 1836, [[Church of Saint Francis Xavier, Liverpool|St Francis Xavier Church, Liverpool]] in 1840, the [[Church of St. Walburge, Preston|St Walburge's Preston]] in 1854, both [[Our Lady Immaculate and St Joseph Church, Prescot]] and [[Sacred Heart Church, Blackpool]] in 1857, [[Holy Cross Church, St Helens]] in 1860, [[St Joseph and St Francis Xavier Church, Richmond]] in 1866, Sacred Heart Church in [[Accrington]] in 1869 and [[Church of St Mary, Lowe House]] in 1924.
===Clayton-le-Moors and Accrington=== From 1810 to 1873, the Jesuits served the Catholics in Clayton-le-Moors from St Mary's Church, until they handed over the administration of the church over to the [[Diocese of Salford]] who continue to serve the parish.<ref>[http://www.lan-opc.org.uk/Clayton-le-Moors/stmary/ St Mary, Clayton le Moors] from ''Online Parish clerks of Lancashire'' retrieved 13 March 2014</ref>
The Jesuits arrived in Accrington in 1852 to start a mission and dedicated the parish to [[Oswald of Northumbria]]. In 1869, a church was built on Blackburn Road and was dedicated to the [[Sacred Heart]] instead. On 5 August 1869 the church was opened by the first [[Bishop of Salford]], [[William Turner (bishop of Salford)|William Turner]]. In 1931, the parish needed expansion and Our Lady's Chapel was built in [[Huncoat]]. In 1958, the Jesuits handed over the administration of the church to the [[Diocese of Salford]]. In June 2003, the church was closed. Later that year, it was damaged in a fire and then demolished.<ref>[http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/LAN/Accrington/SacredHeartoriginallyStOswald.shtml St Oswald] from [[Genuki]] retrieved 13 March 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.accringtonobserver.co.uk/news/local-news/anger-as-firebugs-hit-church-1265604 Anger as firebugs hit church] from ''[[Accrington Observer]]'', 8 September 2003, retrieved 18 January 2016</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Catholicism|Education}} *[[Stonyhurst|Stonyhurst Estate]] *[[College of St Omer]] *[[Stonyhurst Saint Mary's Hall]] *[[Hodder Place]] *[[List of Stonyhurst Alumni/ae]] *[[List of Victoria Crosses by School]] *[[Stonyhurst Gospel]] *[[Roman Catholic Church]] *[[Society of Jesus]] *[[St Ignatius of Loyola|St Ignatius, founder of the Jesuits]] *[[Aloysius Gonzaga|St Aloysius Gonzaga, patron saint]] *[[St Gordianus]], interred in the school *[[English Heritage]] *[[Hurst Green, Lancashire|Hurst Green]] *[[Lancashire]] *[[Forest of Bowland]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Sources== * Chadwick, Hubert, S.J. (1962). ''St Omers to Stonyhurst'', Burns & Oats. No ISBN * Walsh, R.R. (1989) ''Stonyhurst War Record'' * Muir, T.E. (1992). ''Stonyhurst College 1593-1993'', James & James (Publishers) Ltd. {{ISBN|0-907383-32-7}} * Kirby, Henry L. and Walsh, R.Raymond (1987). ''The Seven V.C.s of Stonyhurst College'', T.H.C.L. Books. {{ISBN|0-948494-04-2}} * The Authorities of Stonyhurst College (1963), ''A Stonyhurst Handbook for Visitors and Others'', Third edition * Hewitson, A. (Preston, 1878), ''Stonyhurst College, Present and Past: Its History, Discipline, Treasures and Curiosities'', Second edition * [http://www.stonyhurst.ac.uk Stonyhurst College website]

revision.text:
'''James H. Wyckoff''' is a [[United States|U.S.-American]] [[education economics|education economist]] who currently serves as Curry Memorial Professor of Education and Public Policy at the [[University of Virginia]], where he is also the Director of the Center for Education Policy and Workforce Competitiveness.<ref>[http://batten.virginia.edu/school/people/james-h-wyckoff Faculty profile of James H. Wyckoff on the website of the University of Virginia. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> His research on the impact of teacher compensation on teacher performance (together with [[Thomas Dee]]) has been awarded the Raymond Vernon Memorial Award of the [[Association for Public Policy Analysis and Management]] in 2015.<ref>[http://www.appam.org/jpam-awards-2015-vernon-memorial-prize-/ APPAM (October 13th, 2015). JPAM Awards 2015 Vernon Memorial Prize. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref>
== Biography==
James Wyckoff earned a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[economics]] from [[Denison University]] in 1974 and a [[Ph.D.]] in economics from the [[University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]], in 1982. After his graduation, he became an assistant professor of economics at the [[University of Oklahoma, Norman]] (1982-86) before moving to the [[University at Albany, SUNY]] in 1986, where he worked as assistant professor of [[public administration]] before being promoted to associate professor and then to full professor. Intermittedly, Wyckoff also served as chair of Albany's Department of Public Administration and Policy (1996-98) and as Acting Dean of its Graduate School of Public Affairs (1998-2000). Since 2008, Wyckoff has been a professor at the [[University of Virginia]]'s [[Curry School of Education]] and [[Frank Batten School of Leadership and Public Policy]], where he was honoured with the position of Curry Memorial Professor of Education in 2011. In 2010, he moreover became Director of EdPolicyWorks, also known as the Center on Education Policy and Workforce Competitiveness.<ref>[http://batten.virginia.edu/sites/default/files/person/cv/WyckoffCV2018.pdf Curriculum vitae of James Wyckoff from the website of the University of Virginia. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref>
In terms of professional activities, Wyckoff is affiliated with the [[Association for Education Finance and Policy]], whose president he was in 2004,<ref>[http://www.aefpweb.org/aefp/past-presidents List of past presidents of the AEFP. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> and a member of the policy council of the [[Association for Public Policy Analysis and Management]] (2006-10), among else.<ref>[http://batten.virginia.edu/sites/default/files/person/cv/WyckoffCV2018.pdf Curriculum vitae of James Wyckoff from the website of the University of Virginia. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> Moreover, he sits on the editorial boards of the ''[[Journal of Policy Analysis and Management]]'',<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/page/journal/15206688/homepage/editorialboard.html Editorial Board of the Journal of Policy Analysis and Management. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> ''[[Educational Researcher]]''<ref>[https://uk.sagepub.com/en-gb/afr/journal/educational-researcher#editorial-board Editorial Board of the Educational Researcher. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> and ''[[Education Finance and Policy]]''<ref>[https://www.mitpressjournals.org/journals/edfp/editorial Editorial Board of Education Finance and Policy. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> and has done so in the past for the ''[[Economics of Education Review]]''.<ref>[http://batten.virginia.edu/sites/default/files/person/cv/WyckoffCV2018.pdf Curriculum vitae of James Wyckoff from the website of the University of Virginia. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref>
== Research==
James Wyckoff's research focuses on teacher labour markets, in particular on the preparation, recruitment, assessment and retention of teachers,<ref>[http://batten.virginia.edu/school/people/james-h-wyckoff Faculty profile of James H. Wyckoff on the website of the University of Virginia. Retrieved April 13th, 2018.]</ref> within which he has frequently collaborated with [[Donald Boyd]], [[Susanna Loeb]] and [[Hamilton Lankford]]. However, in the 1990s, Wyckoff has also performed research on e.g. school choice, finding (with Lankford) parents to trade-off between the relative quality of school offerings, the tuition of religious schools, the characteristics of other students in public and religious schools, and their family's socioeconomic characteristics.<ref>[https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/027277579290040A Lankford, H., Wyckoff, J. (1992). Primary and secondary school choice among public and religious alternatives. ''Economics of Education Review'', 11(4), pp. 317-337.]</ref>
Analysing the sorting of teachers by qualifications in [[New York (state)|New York]] with Lankford and Loeb, Wyckoff found that low-income, low-achieving and non-white students, especially in urban schools, are generally taught by the least skilled teachers, with salaries rarely leaning against and sometimes even contributing to this sorting.<ref>[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.3102/01623737024001037 Lankford, H., Loeb, S., Wyckoff, J. (2002). Teacher Sorting and the Plight of Urban Schools: A Descriptive Analysis. ''Educational Evaluation and Policy Analysis'', 24(1), pp. 37-62.]</ref> In further research with Boyd, they find teacher labour markets' spatial scope to be very small as teachers display strong preferences for proximity, which in turn makes it more difficult for urban schools to recruit new, well-qualified teachers.<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/pam.20072 Boyd, D. et al. (2005). The draw of home: How teachers' preferences for proximity disadvantage urban schools. ''Journal of Policy Analysis and Management'', 24(1), pp. 113-132.]</ref> Overall, they attribute teacher sorting to a combination of more qualified teachers being more likely to leave schools with very low-performing students and schools with such students generally experiencing higher turnover than other schools,<ref>[https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/000282805774669628 Boyd, D. et al. (2005). Explaining the short careers of high-achieving teachers in schools with low-performing students. ''American Economic Review'', 95(2), pp. 166-171.]</ref><ref>[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0022487105285943 Boyd, D.J. et al. (2006). Complex by Design: Investigating Pathways Into Teaching in New York City Schools. ''Journal of Teacher Education'', 57(2), pp. 155-166.]</ref> though high growth in student achievement can effectively act as a retention mechanism for effective teachers in low-achieving schools.<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/pam.20545 Boyd, D. et al. (2011). The role of teacher quality in retention and hiring: Using applications to transfer to uncover preferences of teachers and schools. ''Journal of Policy Analysis and Management'', 30(1), pp. 88-110.]</ref> In particular, effective teachers tend to leave low-achieving schools (but not high-achieving schools) within their second and third years at these schools, thereby likely contributing to the widening of the learning outcomes between students; by contrast, less effective teachers tend to leave both low- and high-performing schools within their first year.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Donald |last=Boyd |first2=Pam |last2=Grossman |first3=Hamilton |last3=Lankford |first4=Susanna |last4=Loeb |first5=James |last5=Wyckoff |display-authors=1 |title=Who Leaves? Teacher Attrition and Student Achievement |work=NBER Working Paper No. 14022 |date=May 2008 |doi=10.3386/w14022 }}</ref> Importantly, they also find that the main driver behind teachers' turnover decisions in [[New York City]] is their (negative) perception of the school administration.<ref>[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.3102/0002831210380788 Boyd, D. et al. (2011). The influence of school administrators on teacher retention decisions. ''American Educational Research Journal'', 48(2), pp. 303-333.]</ref> The resulting teacher turnover evidently harms students' test scores in math and English language arts, especially in schools with many Black and low-performing students.<ref>[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.3102/0002831212463813 Ronfeldt, M., Loeb, S., Wyckoff, J. (2013). How Teacher Turnover Harms Student Achievement. ''American Educational Research Journal'', 50(1), pp. 4-36.]</ref>
However, narrowing the gap between the qualifications of teachers in high- and low-performing schools is possible; for example, the NYC Teaching Fellows and Teach for America initiatives were able to substantially reduce such a gap between New York City's low- and high-poverty schools over 2000-2005 by substituting uncertified teachers in high-pverty schools by academically qualified teachers.<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1002/pam.20377 Boyd, D. et al. (2008). The narrowing gap in New York City teacher qualifications and its implications for student achievement in high-poverty schools. ''Journal of Policy Analysis and Management'', 27(4), pp. 793-818.]</ref> Further research by Wyckoff and his co-authors on teachers' preparation and recruitment has found that teachers with reduced pre-job coursework often provide smaller initial gains in both math and English language arts when compared to teachers who completed a university-based teacher education programme, though most differences disappear as the cohort matures<ref>[https://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/edfp.2006.1.2.176 Boyd, D. et al. (2006). How changes in entry requirements alter the teacher workforce and affect student achievement. ''Education Finance and Policy'', 1(2), pp. 176-216.]</ref> and that teacher preparation programmes' vary in their impact on teachers' value added to student test score performance, with practice-based preparation being particularly effective for new teachers.<ref>[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.3102/0162373709353129 Boyd, D.J. et al. (2009). Teacher Preparation and Student Achievement. ''Educational Evaluation and Policy Analysis'', 31(4), pp. 416-440.]</ref> However, in the past, Wyckoff has been cautious to call for specific policies regarding teacher certification and preparation, arguing that the verdict on their impact on teacher quality and student achievement was still out.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/4150019?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents Boyd, D. et al. (2007). The effect of certification and preparation on teacher quality. ''Future of Children'', , 17(1), pp. 45-68.]</ref> Moreover, teachers who have the highest value-added to student test performance have distinctly different instructional practice profiles, e.g. consistently scoring better on Explicit Strategy Instruction.<ref>[https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/669901 Grossman, P. et al. (2013). Measure for measure: The relationship between measures of instructional practice in middle school English language arts and teachers' value-added scores. ''American Journal of Education'', 19(3), pp. 445-470.]</ref> Finally, together with [[Thomas Dee]], Wyckoff has also evaluated IMPACT, the high-powered teacher-evaluation system introduced by [[Michelle Rhee]] in [[Washington D.C.]], and found that dismissal threats increased the voluntary attrition of low-performing teachers and improved the performance of remaining teachers, while financial incentives were effective in further improving the performance of high-performing teachers.<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/a/wly/jpamgt/v34y2015i2p267-297.html Dee, T.S., Wyckoff, J. (2015). Incentives, selection, and teacher performance: Evidence from IMPACT. ''Journal of Policy Analysis and Management'', 34(2), pp. 267-297.]</ref>
== References==
{{reflist}}
== External links==
* [http://batten.virginia.edu/school/people/james-h-wyckoff Faculty profile of James H. Wyckoff]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wyckoff, James}} [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:Denison University alumni]] [[Category:University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill alumni]] [[Category:University of Virginia faculty]] [[Category:Education economists]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Unreferenced|date=January 2007}} KCSE stands for the '''Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education''', which is taken at the completion of Secondary Education.
The first KCSE exam was held in 1989 at the same time as the last [[Kenya Advanced Certificate of Education]] (KACE), which it replaced as the entrance requirement for Kenyan universities.
The top student was Naeem Samnakay, who had also been the top student in the first [[KCPE]] exam four years previously.
Initially, KCSE was a minimum of ten subjects. KCSE has since been reviewed twice, and the minimum number of subjects is now seven.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Compulsory subjects ! Group two ! Group three ! Group four ! Group five |- | [[English language|English]], [[Swahili language|Swahili]], Mathematics | Biology, Physics, Chemistry and Biological Science (taken by blind candidates) | History and Government, Geography, Christian Religious Education, Islamic Religious Education and Hindu Religious Education | Home Science, Art and Design, Agriculture, Computer Studies, Aviation | French, German, Arabic, Music, Business Studies |- |}
For grading, candidates must take all the three compulsory subjects, at least two sciences, one humanities and at least one practical or technical subject (see table below).
The examination is taken over October and November, and the results are released in February the following year.
The KCSE examinations are taken under very strict supervision from invigilators to avoid cheating and run for a period of about one month. Cheating in these examinations attracts severe penalties from the [[Kenya National Examination Council]], and students caught cheating get their grades cancelled.
The exams usually start on October 22 and end in late November. From December, the exam is graded and the results are released in late December the same year.
Examination results are announced to the public by the Minister for Education, and the top hundred students and schools are released to the media the day of the results announcement. School rankings are divided into the top 100 private schools, public schools and provincial schools.
The grading of the examination is as thus: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Grade || Percentage mark |- | A || 80-100 |- | A- || 75-79 |- | B+ || 70-74 |- | B || 65-69 |- | B- || 60-64 |- | C+ || 55-59 |- | C || 50-54 |- | C- || 45-49 |- | D+ || 40-44 |- | D || 35-39 |- | D- || 30-34 |- | E || 0-29 |}
In Kenya, this examination is the entrance to public and private universities and the pass mark is grade C+. Students who attain a lower mark than C+ join other tertiary institutions for non-degree courses. Over time, stringent measures have been taken by the government to ensure and sustain the credibility of the KCSE examination. However, there have been instances of breaches of these measures leading to examination vices such as leakage to some selected students who if undetected end up scoring high grades. In detected cases, such students have been punished by having their results cancelled and examination officials who participated in the cheating charged in a court of law.
Each year, hundreds of thousands of students take the examination after four years of the Secondary School Course and this examination is a major determinant of the individual's future career. A good grade guarantees one a place in one of the public or private universities in the country.
==See also== *[[Kenya National Examination Council]]
== External links == * [http://www.knec.ac.ke The Kenya National Examination Council] * [http://kenyaschoolreport.com/ Kenya School Report] * [http://education254.com/ online Kcse Results] * [http://education254.com/edu/ Internship and attachment in kenya] * [http://www.mwalimu-bora.net/2016/11/Kenya-Certificate-of-Secondary-Education-KCSE-examination-in-Kenya.html Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education Information]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kenya Certificate Of Secondary Education}} [[Category:Education in Kenya]] [[Category:Secondary school qualifications]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[North Korean]] (link changed to [[North Korea]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
'''Konglish''' ({{korean|hangul=콩글리시|hanja=|rr=konggeullisi|mr=}}; {{IPA-ko|kʰoŋ.ɡɯl.li.ɕi|}}), more formally- '''Korean-style English''' ({{korean|hangul=한국어식 영어|hanja=|rr=hangugeo-sik yeongeo|mr=}}; {{IPA-ko|han.ɡu.ɡʌ.ɕik̚ jʌŋ.ʌ|}}) is a style of [[English language|English]] used by [[Korean language|Korean]] speakers.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uiglDwAAQBAJ|title=Attitudes to World Englishes: Implications for Teaching English in South Korea|last=Ahn|first=Hyejeong|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2017|isbn=1315394294|location=|pages=30–33}} Konglish has English [[loanword]]s that have been appropriated into Korean and are used in ways that are [[Pseudo-anglicism|not readily understandable]] to native English speakers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/09/beauty-perils-konglish-korean-english-hybrid/|title=The Rise of Konglish, the Korean-English Hybrid That’s Both Beautiful and Perilous|last=Rhodes|first=Margaret|date=2016-09-29|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-01-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QTXdAwAAQBAJ|title=Korean English: A corpus-driven study of a new English|last=Hadikin|first=Glenn|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|year=2014|isbn=9027269947|location=|pages=8–12}} A common example is the Korean term "hand phone" for the English "[[mobile phone]]."{{Cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150722001132|title=‘Konglish’ floods into apartment brand names|last=Suk|first=Gee-hyun|date=2015-07-22|work=The Korea Herald|access-date=2018-01-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} Konglish also has direct English loanwords, mistranslations from English to Korean, or [[Wasei-eigo|pseudo-English words coined in Japan]] that came to Korean usage. The use of Konglish is widespread in [[South Korea]] as a result of [[United States|U.S.]] cultural influence, but it is not familiar to [[North Korea|North Koreans]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/after-70-years-of-division-north-and-south-koreans-losing-shared-language/article23462242/|title=After 70 years of division, North and South Koreans losing shared language|last=Kim|first=Hyung-Jin|date=2017-03-25|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2018-01-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|agency=Associated Press}} == Examples == This list of Konglish terms generally contains Konglish terms [[Pseudo-anglicism|not readily understandable]] to a native [[English language|English]] speaker, similar to ''[[wasei-eigo]]'' terms in the [[Japanese language]]. Many Konglish terms were invented by [[Koreans]] through non-standard abbreviations or combinations of English words or by applying a new meaning or usage to a common English word. {{dynamic list}} * di-ca – "[[digital camera]]"
''dika'' ({{lang|ko|디카}} {{IPA-ko|ti.kʰa|}}) < digital camera * hand phone – "[[mobile phone]]"
''haendeupon'' ({{lang|ko|핸드폰}} {{IPA-ko|hɛn.dɯ.pon|}}) < hand + phone * sel-ca – "[[selfie]]"
''selka'' ({{lang|ko|셀카}} {{IPA-ko|sel.kʰa|}}) < self + camera * eye shopping - "window shopping"
''ai-syoping'' ({{lang|ko|아이쇼핑}} {{IPA-ko|a.i.ɕjo.pʰiŋ|}}) < eye + shopping * hot dog – "[[corn dog]]"
''hatdogeu'' ({{lang|ko|핫도그}} {{IPA-ko|hat̚.t͈o.ɡɯ|}}) < hot + dog * [[officetel]] – "an apartment that can also be used as an office"
''opiseutel'' ({{lang|ko|오피스텔}} {{IPA-ko|o.pʰi.sɯ.tʰel|}}) < office + hotel * overeat – "vomiting"
''obaiteu'' ({{lang|ko|오바이트}} {{IPA-ko|o.ba.i.tʰɯ|}}) < overeat * poclain – "excavator"
''pokeullein'' ({{lang|ko|포클레인}} {{IPA-ko|pʰo.kʰɯl.le.in|}}) < [[Poclain]] * self – "[[self-service]]"
''selpeu'' ({{lang|ko|셀프}} {{IPA-ko|sel.pʰɯ|}}) < self * skin-scuba – "[[wikt:skin diving|skin diving]] and [[scuba diving]]"
''seukin-seukubeo'' ({{lang|ko|스킨스쿠버}} {{IPA-ko|sɯ.kʰin.sɯ.kʰu.bʌ|}}) < skin + scuba * soul food – "[[comfort food]]"
''soul-pudeu'' ({{lang|ko|소울푸드}} {{IPA-ko|so.ul.pʰu.dɯ|}}) < soul + food * [[webtoon]] – "[[webcomic]]"
''weptun'' ({{lang|ko|웹툰}} {{IPA-ko|wep̚.tʰun|}}) < web + cartoon === Loanwords from Japan === Many loanwords entered into Korean from [[Japan]], especially during the [[Japanese forced occupation]], when the teaching and speaking of Korean was prohibited.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=EhXrBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT35|title=Moon Living Abroad in South Korea|last=Hopfner|first=Jonathan|publisher=[[Moon Publications]]|year=2009|isbn=978-1-59880-250-4|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=25}} Those Konglish words are loanwords from, and thus similar to, [[Wasei-eigo]] used in Japan. A simple example would be how the meaning of the English word "cunning" changes when used in a Konglish sentence. In South Korea, ''keonning'' means cheating, as the loanword was adapted from [[Japanglish]] ''kanningu'' ({{lang|ja|カンニング}}), which means "cheating".{{cite web|url=https://ja.scribd.com/document/12826618/Korea-Herald-20080116|title=Time to clean up cunning Konglish|last=Smith|first=Sean|date=January 16, 2008|publisher=The Korea Herald}} Konglish words may or may not have a similar meaning to the original word when used, and a well-known [[brand name]] can become a generalized trademark and replace the general word: older Korean people tend to use the word ''babari'' ("[[Burberry]]") or ''babari-koteu'' ("Burberry coat"), which came from Japanese ''bābari-kōto'' (meaning "gabardine raincoat") to refer to all [[trench coat]]s. Coates made by Burberry are called ''beobeori-koteu'' ({{lang|ko|버버리 코트}}), rather than ''babari-koteu'' in Korean (as the brand name, entered to Korean language directly from English, is ''Beobeori''). {{dynamic list}} * after service, A/S – "[[customer service]]", "[[warranty]]"
''apeuteo-seobiseu'' ({{lang|ko|애프터서비스}} {{IPA-ko|ɛ.pɯ.tʰʌ.sʌ.bi.sɯ|}}) < ''afutā-sābisu'' ({{lang|ja|アフターサービス}} {{IPA-ja|a.ɸɯ̟ᵝ.taː.saːbi.sɨᵝ|}}) < after + service * apart – "[[apartment]] building"
''apateu'' ({{lang|ko|아파트}} {{IPA-ko|a.pʰa.tʰɯ|}}) < ''apāto'' ({{lang|ja|アパート}} {{IPA-ja|a.paː.to̞|}}) < apartment * auto-bi – "motorcycle"
''otobai'' ({{lang|ko|오토바이}} {{IPA-ko|o.tʰo.ba.i|}}) < ''ōtobai'' ({{lang|ja|オートバイ}} {{IPA-ja|o̞ː.to̞.ba.i|}}) < auto + bicycle * back mirror – "[[rear-view mirror]]""
''baengmireo'' ({{lang|ko|백미러}} {{IPA-ko|pɛŋ.mi.ɾʌ|}}) < ''bakku-mirā'' ({{lang|ja|バックミラー}} {{IPA-ja|ba.kɯ̟ᵝ.mi.ɾ̠aː|}}) < back + mirror * Burberry coat – "[[trench coat]]"
''babari-koteu'' ({{lang|ko|바바리코트}} {{IPA-ko|pa.ba.ɾi.kʰo.tʰɯ|}}) < ''bābari-kōto'' ({{lang|ja|バーバリコート}} {{IPA-ja|baː.ba.ɾ̠i.ko̞ː.to̞|}}, "gabardine raincoat") < [[Burberry]] coat * career woman – "a woman who works"
''keorieo-umeon'' ({{lang|ko|커리어우먼}} {{IPA-ko|kʰʌ.ɾi.ʌ.u.mʌn|}}) < ''kyaria-ūman'' ({{lang|ja|キャリアウーマン}} {{IPA-ja|kja.ɾ̠i.a.ɯ̟ᵝː.mãɴ|}}) < career + woman * carrier – "[[suit case]]"
''kaerieo'' ({{lang|ko|캐리어}} {{IPA-ko|kʰɛ.ɾi.ʌ|}}) < ''kyarībaggu'' ({{lang|ja|キャリーバッグ}} {{IPA-ja|kja.ɾ̠i.a.bag.gɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < carrier + bag * cider – "[[lemon-lime drink]]"
''saida'' ({{lang|ko|사이다}} {{IPA-ko|sa.i.da|}}) < ''saidā'' ({{lang|ja|サイダー}} {{IPA-ja|sa.i.daː|}}) < cider * cunning – "cheating"
''keoning'' ({{lang|ko|커닝}} {{IPA-ko|kʰʌ.niŋ|}}) or ''keonning'' ({{lang|ko|컨닝}} {{IPA-ko|kʰʌn.niŋ|}}) < ''kanningu'' ({{lang|ja|カンニング}} {{IPA-ja|kãn.nĩŋ.ɡɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < cunning * ero – "lewd"
''ero'' ({{lang|ko|에로}} {{IPA-ko|e.ɾo|}}) < ''ero'' (エロ {{IPA-ja|e̞.ɾ̠o̞|}}) < erotic * fancy – "stationery"
''paensi'' ({{lang|ko|팬시}} {{IPA-ko|pʰɛn.ɕi|}}) < ''fanshī-shōhin'' ({{lang|ja|ファンシー商品}} {{IPA-ja|ɸãɰ̃.ɕiː.ɕo̞ː.hin|}}; "illustrated goods") < fancy + Japanese "goods" * fighting – "Go go go!", "Good luck!", "You can do it!"
''paiting'' ({{lang|ko|파이팅}} {{IPA-ko|pʰa.i.tiŋ|}}) or ''hwaiting'' ({{lang|ko|화이팅}} {{IPA-ko|hwa.i.tiŋ|}}) < ''faito'' ({{lang|ja|ファイト}} {{IPA-ja|ɸa.i.to|}}) < fight * gag man – "comedian"
''gaegeu-man'' ({{lang|ko|개그맨}} {{IPA-ko|kɛ.ɡɯ.mɛn|}}) < ''gyagu-man'' ({{lang|ja|ギャグマン}} {{IPA-ja|ɡja.ɡɯ̟ᵝ.mãɴ|}}) < gag + man *gag woman – "comedian"
''gaegeu-woman'' ({{lang|ko|개그우먼}} {{IPA-ko|kɛ.ɡɯ.u.mʌn|}}) < ''gyagu-man'' ({{lang|ja|ギャグウーマン}} {{IPA-ja|ɡja.ɡɯ̟ᵝ.ɯ̟ᵝː.mãɴ|}}) < gag + woman * glamour – "a buxom woman"
''geullaemeo'' ({{lang|ko|글래머}} {{IPA-ko|kɯl.lɛ.mʌ|}}) < ''guramā-gāru'' ({{lang|ja|グラマーガール}} {{IPA-ja|ɡɯ̟ᵝ.ɾ̠a.maː.ɡaː.ɾ̠ɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < glamour + girl * handle – "[[steering wheel]]"
''haendeul'' ({{lang|ko|핸들}} {{IPA-ko|hɛn.dɯl|}}) < ''handoru'' ({{lang|ja|ハンドル}} {{IPA-ja|hãn.do̞.ɾ̠ɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < handle * hotchkiss – "[[stapler]]"
''hochikiseu'' ({{lang|ko|호치키스}} {{IPA-ko|ho.tɕʰi.kʰi.sɯ|}}) < ''hochikisu'' ({{lang|ja|ホチキス}} {{IPA-ja|ho̞.tɕi.ki.sɨᵝ|}}) < American brand name E. H. Hotchkiss Company * missing – "[[sewing machine]]"
''mising'' ({{lang|ko|미싱}} {{IPA-ko|mi.ɕiŋ|}}) < ''mishin'' ({{lang|ja|ミシン}} {{IPA-ja|mi.ɕĩɴ|}}) < machine * morning call – "wakeup call"
''moning-kol'' ({{lang|ko|모닝콜}} {{IPA-ko|mo.niŋ.kʰol|}}) < ''mōningu-kōru'' ({{lang|ja|モーニングコール}} {{IPA-ja|mo̞ː.nĩŋ.ɡɯ̟ᵝ.ko̞ː.ɾ̠ɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < morning + call * one-piece – "[[dress]]"
''wonpiseu'' ({{lang|ko|원피스}} {{IPA-ko|wʌn.pʰi.sɯ|}}) < ''wanpīsu'' ({{lang|ja|ワンピース}} {{IPA-ja|ɰᵝãm.piː.sɨᵝ|}}) < one + piece * one-room – "[[studio apartment]]"
''wollum'' ({{lang|ko|원룸}} {{IPA-ko|wʌl.lum|}}) < ''wanrūmumanshon'' ({{lang|ja|ワンルームマンション}} {{IPA-ja|ɰᵝãɰ̃.ɾ̠ɯ̟ᵝː.mɯ̟ᵝ.mãɰ̃.ɕõ̞ɴ|}}) < one + room + mansion * remo-con – "remote control"
''rimokeon'' ({{lang|ko|리모컨}} {{IPA-ko|ɾi.mo.kʌn|}}) < ''rimokon'' ({{lang|ja|リモコン}} {{IPA-ja|ɾ̠i.mo.kõ̞ɴ|}}) < remote + control * running machine – "[[treadmill]]"
''reoning-meosin'' ({{lang|ko|러닝머신}} {{IPA-ko|ɾʌ.niŋ.mʌ.ɕin|}}) < ''ranningu-mashīn'' ({{lang|ja|ランニングマシーン}} {{IPA-ja|ɾ̠ãn.niŋ.ɡɯ̟ᵝ.ma.ɕĩːɴ|}}) < running + machine * service – "something that is free of charge"Pyon, Elizabeth (June 25, 2002) [Letters to the Editor] Konglish: It's not that bad. THE KOREA HERALD, Retrieved from www.lexisnexis.com/hottopics/lnacademic
''seobiseu'' ({{lang|ko|서비스}} {{IPA-ko|sʌ.bi.sɯ|}}) < ''sābisu'' ({{lang|ja|サービス}} {{IPA-ja|saː.bi.sɨᵝ|}}) < service * sharp – "mechanical pencil"
''syapeu'' ({{lang|ko|샤프}} {{IPA-ko|ɕja.pʰɯ|}}) < ''shāpupenshiru'' ({{lang|ja|シャープペンシル}} {{IPA-ja|ɕaː.pɯ̟ᵝ.pẽɰ̃.ɕi.ɾ̠ɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < sharp + pencil * skinship – "physical contact"
''seukinsip'' ({{lang|ko|스킨십}} {{IPA-ko|sɯ.kʰin.ɕip̚|}}) < ''sukinshippu'' ({{lang|ja|スキンシップ}} {{IPA-ja|sɨᵝ.kij̃.ɕip.pɯ̟ᵝ|}}) < skin + -ship * super – "corner shop"{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/opinion/2017/04/197_207412.html|title=Not Konglish (Part 2). Korea Times|date=June 20, 2016|publisher=The Korea Times}}
''syupeo'' ({{lang|ko|슈퍼}} {{IPA-ko|ɕju.pʰʌ|}}) < ''sūpā'' ({{lang|ja|スーパー}} {{IPA-ja|sɨᵝː.paː|}}) < supermarket * talent - "[[Drama (film and television)|televised drama]] actor"
''taelleonteu'' ({{lang|ko|탤런트}} {{IPA-ko|tʰɛl.lʌn.tʰɯ|}}) < ''[[tarento]]'' ({{lang|ja|タレント}} {{IPA-ja|ta.ɾ̠ẽ̞n.to̞|}}) < talent * tape cleaner - "[[lint remover]]"
''teipeu-keullineo'' ({{lang|ko|테이프클리너}} {{IPA-ko|tʰe.i.pʰɯ.kʰɯl.li.nʌ|}}) < ''tēpu-kurīnā'' ({{lang|ja|テープクリーナー}} {{IPA-ja|te̞ː.pɰᵝ.kɰᵝ.ɾ̠iː.naː|}}) < tape + cleaner * two piece - "skirt or pants and a top"
''tupiseu'' ({{lang|ko|투피스}} {{IPA-ko|tʰu.pʰi.sɯ|}}) < ''tsūpīsu'' ({{lang|ja|ツーピース}} {{IPA-ja|tsɨᵝː.piː.sɨᵝ|}}) < two + piece * vinyl house – "green house"
''binil-hauseu'' ({{lang|ko|비닐하우스}} {{IPA-ko|pi.nil.ha.u.sɯ|}}) < ''binīru-hausu'' ({{lang|ja|ビニールハウス}} {{IPA-ja|bi.niː.ɾ̠ɯ̟ᵝ.ha.ɯ̟ᵝ.sɨᵝ|}}) < vinyl + house * Y-shirt – "[[dress shirt]]"
''wai-sheocheu'' ({{lang|ko|와이셔츠}} {{IPA-ko|wa.i.ɕjʌ.tɕʰɯ|}}) < ''wai-shatsu'' ({{lang|ja|ワイシャツ}} {{IPA-ja|ɰᵝa.i.ɕa.tsɨᵝ|}})) < white shirt === Pseudo-Konglish loanwords === Some foreign-origin words such as ''areubaiteu'' ({{lang|ko|아르바이트}}, {{IPA-ko|a.ɾɯ.ba.i.tʰɯ|}}, "[[part-time]]"), a loanword from [[German language|German]] ''{{lang|de|Arbeit}}'' ({{IPA-de|ˈar.baɪ̯t|}}, "work"), are sometimes mistakenly considered as Konglish and are corrected into "accurate" English loanword forms such as ''pateutaim'' ({{lang|ko|파트타임}}, {{IPA-ko|pʰa.tʰɯ.tʰa.im|}}). === Apartment names === A trend in the naming of apartment buildings in [[Seoul]] is blending English words together because developers believe this will enhance the luxury brand image of the properties.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150722001132|title='Konglish' floods into apartment brand names|date=July 22, 2015|publisher=The Korea Herald}} Some examples of apartment names with blended English words include: Luxtige, Blesstige, Tristige and Forestige, XI; these words are combinations of luxury, bless, prestige, trinity, forest, extra and intelligence. == Criticism == Misuse or corruption of the English language by Koreans learning [[English as a foreign language]] have also been referred to as Konglish.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2076122|title=Konglish inquiry traces evidence back to poor textbooks|author=Jeremy Garlick|date=24 December 2003|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=2 August 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/special_list.asp?categoryCode=221|title=Konglish Special News Section|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}} This section has photos and short descriptions which highlight Konglish use around Korea. These are often all vocabulary/grammar errors.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1905811|title=One word at a time|author=Park Soo-mee|date=8 June 2002|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Using English words in daily conversation, advertising, and entertainment is seen as trendy and [[Cool (aesthetic)|cool]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} However this use can often lead to misunderstandings due to problems with [[English phonology|pronunciation]], [[English grammar|grammar]] or vocabulary.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2887839|title=It’s just not cool to mangle the King’s English|author=sujiney AT joongang.co.kr|date=26 March 2008|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Modern use of Konglish has already created a linguistic divide between [[North Korea]] and South Korea. [[North Korean defectors]] can have trouble integrating into South Korean society because much of the Konglish used there is not used in North Korea. This can lead to confusion, misunderstandings and delay in integration into the society. This is not the sole cause of the linguistic divide between the two nations as some Korean words are also used differently between the two countries.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2882555|title=A wordy problem faces the Koreas|author=Lee Eun-joo|date=10 November 2007|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=2 August 2009}} While Konglish problems exist between the North and South they also exist between the metropolitan and rural.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1998509|title=[VIEWPOINT]Divided by a common language|author=Rick Ruffin|date=23 June 2003|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Ahn Jung-hyo, a Korean-English translator who is the author of "A False English Dictionary," was noted for saying that improper use of Konglish in other countries is likely to bring shame to Korea.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=1904723|title=English? Konglish? Purists concede to 'fighting' cheer|author=Kim Hyo-jin|date=10 June 2002|publisher=JoongAng Daily|accessdate=2 August 2009}} However, John Huer, a columnist for Korea Times, noted Konglish usage as one of his "10 Most Wonderful Things About Korea". He felt that it was both inventive and clever.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2009/04/117_42610.html|title=Secret Pact With Lower Class|author=John Huer|date=5 April 2009|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}} After that article Huer criticized Koreans for their bad English and improper use of loanwords, though.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2009/07/202_49030.html|title=Is English in Korea Only for Koreans?|author=John Huer|date=24 July 2009|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Modern Konglish usage could even be viewed as art, yet there is a difference between a cultural use of a word like "Fighting!" and the bad grammar and vocabulary seen on signs, packages, and TV around Korea. Sebastian Harrisan has suggested that calling these kinds of things Konglish masks the problem with English education in Korea.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/2009/07/177_2918.html|title=The State of the Art|author=Sebastian Harrisan|date=15 May 2007|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}} The Korean government has been criticized by civic groups for their use of Konglish in slogans and focusing too much on English education. They feel that the heavy focus on English will damage the Korean language and doesn't benefit international competitiveness.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/01/117_18210.html|title=Groups Call for Scrapping of `English-Worshipping'|author=Kim Rahn|date=30 January 2008|publisher=Korea Times|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117091424/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2008/01/117_18210.html|archivedate=January 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2 August 2009}} In contrast, [[Jasper Kim]], a law professor at [[Ewha Womans University]], wrote that Konglish is necessary in a global context and that strict adherence to grammatical rules shouldn't trump getting the message across.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.co.kr/service/print.asp?tpl=print&sname=Special&img=/img/pic/ico_spe_pic.gif&id=200608240028|title=[New Perspective]Konglish as a second language?|author=Jasper Kim|date=24 August 2008|publisher=Korea Herald|accessdate=2 August 2009}} The spread of Konglish in the Korean language has been cited as a reason to increase Koreans' exposure to native English speakers, especially during their educational time. Koreans instructing others can lead to cementing errors into the language.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/include/print.asp?newsIdx=35124|title=Future of English Language Teaching|author=Tory S. Thorkelson|date=26 November 2008|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Poor planning in the education system can result in unqualified Korean teachers being chosen to teach English with little or no time to prepare. These teachers end up using Konglish in the classroom.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.co.kr/service/print.asp?tpl=print&sname=Special&img=/img/pic/ico_spe_pic.gif&id=200609270062|title=Korea`s `English` classrooms: Held hostage by Konglish?|author=Cho Ji-hyun|date=27 September 2006|publisher=Korea Herald|accessdate=2 August 2009}} Even teachers who prepare may end up using official materials that contain numerous errors and Konglish.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.co.kr/service/print.asp?tpl=print&sname=Special&img=/img/pic/ico_spe_pic.gif&id=200405190009|title=[A READER'S VIEW]High stakes in English tests|author=Andrew Finch|date=19 May 2004|publisher=Korea Herald|accessdate=2 August 2009}} This can create a feeling of passiveness towards learning structurally and technically correct English. Students look to teachers as the example and if teachers are making mistakes, these are passed on to them.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/apr/27/highereducation.internationaleducationnews|title='Konglish' replaces good English|author=David Cohen|date=27 April 2001|publisher=Guardian|accessdate=2 August 2009}} The issue of bad Konglish has been raised in relation to tourism. There is a concern that poor English on signs, brochures, websites, or in other media might cause tourists to find another destination.{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/2009/08/260_32552.html|title=Recommendations for Upgrading Tourism|author=David A. Mason|date=12 October 2008|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2009/07/162_37376.html|title=How Can Korea Attract Tourists?|author=Matt Doyon|date=6 January 2009|publisher=Korea Times|accessdate=2 August 2009}} This is a concern not just in small or remote venues, but even major international locations like [[Incheon Airport]]. When the airport was first opened for business more than 49 signs were found to contain English errors. In addition to keeping away tourists, Konglish usage can lead to the breakdown of business deals. Misunderstandings might lead a foreign business partner to lose confidence in a Korean company.{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200001/200001140271.html|title=The Competitive Power of English|publisher=[[Chosun Ilbo]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040524100452/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200001/200001140271.html|archivedate=24 May 2004|accessdate=2 August 2009}} In 2010, a poll showed that 44% of local governments in South Korea used an English phrase in their [[marketing]] [[slogan]].{{cite news|url=http://koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/07/116_68703.html|title=English logos popular, but often humorous|last=Tae-hoon|first=Lee|date=2010-07-02|accessdate=2011-01-01|publisher=[[Korea Times]]}} The slogans at the time included: Lucky [[Dongjak]], Dynamic [[Busan]], Yes [[Gumi, South Korea|Gumi]], Colorful [[Daegu]], [[Ulsan]] for You, Happy [[Suwon]], New Start! [[Yesan]], Super [[Pyeongtaek]], Hi-Touch [[Gongju]], Nice [[Jecheon]] and Just [[Sangju]]. == See also == * [[Contemporary culture of South Korea]] * [[Engrish]] * [[List of Korea-related topics]] * [[Pseudo-anglicism]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.tefl.net/alexcase/tesol/konglish-a-to-z/ An A to Z of Korean English (Konglish) expressions] *[http://www.koreanwikiproject.com/wiki/index.php?title=Konglish koreanwikiproject.com Konglish] {{interlanguage varieties}} {{Korea topics}} [[Category:Education in South Korea]] [[Category:Korean language]] [[Category:Macaronic forms of English]] [[Category:South Korean culture]] [[Category:South Korean society]]

revision.comment: Linked "Ensigns" to [[Ensign (rank)]] instead of article regarding the type of flag.
revision.text:
[[Image:Lanceroinsignia.png|thumb|right|300px|Lancero insignia as worn by military personnel upon completion of the course.]]
'''Lancero''' (''English: [[Lancer]]'') is a military course and a denomination within the [[Colombian Army]]. The course takes place at the School of Lanceros of Colombia in [[Tolemaida]], [[Department of Tolima]] in [[Colombia]]. [[File:Torre de Salto Tolemaida.jpg|thumb|300px]]
== Overview == The Colombian Army has been in a [[Colombian armed conflict|military conflict]] with rebel [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrillas]] since the 1960s. This has led the Colombian Government and its military forces to develop courses specifically aimed to the training of both soldiers and officers for this kind of [[warfare]]. The term Lancero was chosen as a way to honor a specific unit of fighters (Lanceros) that helped the army of [[Simón Bolívar]] in his conflict for the independence of Colombia. This unit showed special bravery and strength during the [[Vargas Swamp Battle]].
==History of the Course== The course was created as a result of the reform that took place inside the National Army of Colombia organization during the early 60s as a way to specialize and refocus the national army towards an [[Irregular military|irregular conflict]] with armed peasants in the mountains of Colombia. Inexperienced and with little knowledge of guerrilla warfare the Colombian Army sent its own officers to [[Fort Benning]] in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], United States so they could take the Ranger Course that takes place there and as a way to apply their acquired knowledge in Colombia's specific situation.
The techniques learned in the American course were modified and taught to [[Sergeant]]s, [[Lieutenant]]s, [[Ensign (rank)|Ensigns]], [[Corporal]]s and some enlisted and ranking officers of the Naval Infantry. This techniques were later spread across all the Colombian military components.
In 1959 the army created companies of Lanceros. These newly created companies were more agile and flexible thus, leading to more successful operations. They were added as supportive personnel for units where the enemy was even more aggressive and active.
In 1966 an outbreak of dispersed bandits called for the creation of even sharper and faster units. This year the Colombian Army's military command put into effect a more extensive training program to combat the rebels; this program would later become a single course called "''Contraguerrillas''"
Since this time the Lancero course has focused on the training of Soldiers, Army Officers and even Police Officers for the needs of a country with an [[Asymmetric warfare|enemy that hides among the civilian population]]. After more than forty years the course has gained some notoriety among military personnel around the [[Earth|globe]] largely due to its focusing on guerrilla warfare and not on regular military warfare.<ref>[http://www.ejercito.mil.co/index.php?idcategoria=92 Escuela de Lanceros - Ejército Nacional de Colombia<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==The Lancero and Lanza concept== The term Lancero which can be translated as [[lancer]] has subsequently led to the use of the term Lanza ([[Lance]]) as a way to refer to a fellow soldier. In fact the course has emphasized on the importance of cooperative work between two soldiers as a way to accomplish goals (one being the Lanza or spear and the other one being the lancero or lance carrier). Thus, the terms Lanza and Lancero are both colloquial and honoring ways to call a fellow soldier or an officer.<ref>[http://www.militaryphotos.net/forums/showthread.php?t=128137 French Foreign Legion in Colombian Lancero course - Military Photos<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

{{see also|List of archives}}
'''National archives''' are central [[archive|archives]] maintained by [[countries]]. This article contains a '''list of [[national archives]]'''.
Among its more important tasks are to ensure the accessibility and preservation of the information produced by governments, both analogically and digitally, for the government itself, researchers and generations to come.
Some national archives collections are large, holding millions of items spanning several centuries, while others created recently have modest collections. In the last decade, digitization projects have made possible to browse records and contents online, although no archive have their entire collections published on the web.

{{about||the psychiatrist|Louise Howard (psychiatrist)}} {{Infobox person | name = Louise Howard | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Louise Ernestine Matthaei | birth_date = {{birth date|1880|12|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kensington]], [[London]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1969|3|11|1880|12|26|df=y}} | death_place = [[Blackheath, London]] | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Cambridge]] | occupation = | religion = | party = | spouse = Sir [[Albert Howard]] | relations = [[Gabrielle Howard]] (sister), E. R. Matthaei (brother), Marie A Matthaei }} '''Louise Ernestine Howard''' (''née'' '''Matthaei'''; 26 December 1880 – 11 March 1969) was a classics scholar, international civil servant and supporter of [[organic farming]].
== Early life and career ==
Born at [[Kensington]], she was the fourth daughter and the youngest of five children of the commission merchant Carl Hermann Ernst Matthaei and the musician Louise Henriette Elizabeth Sueur. Her eldest sister was the botanist [[Gabrielle Howard]]. The family was of German, French and Swiss ancestry. Howard attended [[South Hampstead High School]] and [[Newnham College, Cambridge]]. After obtaining a number of scholarships and prizes, she graduated with [[first-class honours]] in both parts of the classical [[tripos]] and eventually obtained a research fellowship. Howard was seen as a strict but encouraging and sympathetic teacher, having been appointed lecturer and director of studies in classics at Newnham College in 1909.<ref name=odnb>{{citation|title=Howard, Louise Ernestine|last=Oldfield|first=Sybil|work=[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/37576|accessdate=2 January 2013}}</ref>
Following the outbreak of the [[First World War]], the half-German Howard, a supporter of the [[Spartacus League]], attempted to procure an understanding of [[German Empire|Germany]] and fight against collective paranoia. She was dismissed by the [[University of Cambridge]] because her father was German.<ref name=levenback>{{citation|title=Virginia Woolf and the Great War|last=Levenback|first=Karen L.|publisher=Syracuse University Press|year=1999|isbn=0815605463}}</ref> In 1918, Howard became an assistant to [[Leonard Woolf]]. She is alleged to have been the historical model for Miss Kilman, the repulsive and over-educated woman in Virginia Woolfe's famous novel [[Mrs Dalloway]].
Two years later, in Geneva, she successfully completed examination and joined the agricultural section of the [[International Labour Organization]]. In 1924, she became its chief.<ref name="odnb" />
== Marriage ==
In 1931, she married her brother-in-law [[Albert Howard]], a botanist and widower of her sister Gabrielle who had died the previous year. Albert Howard had no children by either of the sisters. By getting involved in her husband's campaign against the use of chemicals in agriculture, she continued her sister's support for his work, becoming known as Lady Howard when he received a knighthood in 1934. In the 1930s and 1940s, Lady Howard helped Germans fleeing from the Nazi regime. After her husband's death in 1947, she founded the Albert Howard Foundation, which merged with the [[Soil Association]] in 1953. Lady Howard was honorary vice president of the latter until her death in [[Blackheath, London]], in 1969.<ref name=odnb/>
== Publications ==
* ''The Lover of the Nations'', 1915. * ''Studies in Greek Tragedy'', 1918. * ''Labour in Agriculture, an International Survey'', 1935. * ''What Country Women Use'', 1939 (together with [[Beryl Hearnden]]) * ''Farming and Gardening for Health or Disease'', 1945 (together with Sir Albert). * ''The Earth's Green Carpet'', 1947. * ''Sir Albert Howard in India'', 1953.

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Mary D. Lowman |image = Mary D. Loman ca 1893.jpg |alt = Photo of Mary D. Lowman |caption = Mary D. Lowman, ca. 1893 |office = [[Oskaloosa, Kansas]] |term_start = 1888 |term_end = 1890 |birth_date = January 27, 1842 |birth_place = [[Indiana County, Pennsylvania]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1912|06|02|1842|01|27}} |death_place = Oskaloosa, Kansas |birthname = Mary D. McGaha |nationality = American |party = |spouse = George W. Lowman |occupation = Schoolteacher }} [[File:Oskaloosa Kansas mayor and council 1888.jpg|thumb|Engraving of the all-women city administration of Oskaloosa, Kansas, 1888, with a view of the city. Clockwise from upper left: Mayor Mary D. Lawson and Councilwomen Carrie Johnson, Sadie E. Balsley, Mittie Josephine Golden, Emma K. Hamilton, and Hanna P. Morse.]] '''Mary D. (McGaha) Lowman''' (January 27, 1842 – June 12, 1912)<ref name=century/><ref name=kshs/><ref name=dates/> was a schoolteacher and the mayor of [[Oskaloosa, Kansas]], in the late 1880s. She was the first woman in Kansas to be elected mayor with a city council composed entirely of women.
==Biography== Mary D. McGaha was born on a farm in [[Indiana County, Pennsylvania]].<ref name=century/> She became a schoolteacher and in 1866 married a man named George W. Lowman, with whom she had two children.<ref name=century/> They moved to Kansas and settle in the small town of Oskaloosa, where she became a teacher of recently [[Emancipation Proclamation|emancipated]] black students.<ref name=century/>
In 1885, she became the city's deputy [[county clerk]] and deputy [[recorder of deeds|register of deeds]].<ref name=century/><ref name=leslie1888/> In 1888, the women of Oskaloosa, dissatisfied with poor city management, decided to run an entire slate of women for municipal office.<ref name=century/><ref name=leslie1888/> (Although American women did not yet have a national [[Women's suffrage in the United States|right to vote]], Kansas women had been given the right to vote in some municipal elections one year earlier.)<ref name=weatherford/> The "Oskaloosa Improvement Ticket"<ref name=murray/> won by a two-to-one margin,<ref name=leslie1888/> making Lowman the first woman in Kansas to serve as mayor with a city council composed entirely of women.<ref name=century/> Newspapers across the country covered the unusual election of an all-women municipal administration.<ref name=kshs/> Lowman was elected only a year after [[Susanna M. Salter]] became the nation's first woman mayor.
When Lowman and her council took office, the city treasury was empty and the city in debt.<ref name=century/> Lowman and her 5-member council were re-elected after their first year in office, with two members of the council being replaced by other women.<ref name=century/><ref name=kshs/> After two years in office, Lowman and her council left the city with a replenished treasury.<ref name=century/>
Lowman died in 1912 of burns received when her clothing caught fire at a cookstove.<ref name=kshs/>
==References== {{reflist | refs
<ref name=dates>One source (Martin 1912) lists Lowman as 72 at the time of her death, which if correct would make her birth year 1840 rather than 1842 (Willard 1893).</ref>
<ref name=weatherford>Weatherford, Doris. ''Women in American Politics: History and Milestones''. SAGE Publications, 2012, p. 240.</ref>
<ref name=murray>Murray, Janet Horowitz, and Myra Stark, eds. ''The Englishwoman's Review of Social and Industrial Questions: 1888'', Routledge Library Editions, n.p.</ref>
<ref name=kshs>Martin, Geo. W., ed. ''Collections of the Kansas State Historical Society 1911–1912''. Topeka, KS: State Printing Office, 1912, p. 400.</ref>
<ref name=leslie1888>"The Latest Kansas Innovation: A Municipal Government Composed of Women". ''Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper'', vols. 65–67, pp. 149–151 (April 21, 1888).</ref>
<ref name=century>Willard, Frances Elizabeth. ''A woman of the century: Fourteen hundred-seventy biographical sketches accompanied by portraits of leading American women in all walks of life''. New York: Moulton, 1893, p. 476.</ref> }}

{{Other uses|Music for People (disambiguation){{!}}Music for People}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Music for People |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = MusicForPeople Logo.jpg |msize = 250px |mcaption = |abbreviation = MfP |motto = There are no "unmusical" people, only those with no musical experience |formation = 1986 |extinction = |type = Non-profit organization |status = |purpose = |headquarters = Goshen, Connecticut, USA |location = |region_served = |membership = 453 (2011) |language = |leader_title = President of the Board |leader_name = James Oshinsky, Ph.D. |leader_title2 = Executive Director |leader_name2 = Eric Miller, Ph.D. |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = 6 |num_volunteers = 11 |budget = |website = http://www.MusicForPeople.org/ |remarks = }} '''Music for People''' ('''MfP''') is a non-profit organization dedicated to music-making and music improvisation as a means of self-expression. Their primary activities include organizing workshops for improvisational music, hosting a four-year ''Musicianship and Leadership Program'' that provides training in music facilitation, and publishing various resources related to improvisational music.
Music for People was founded in 1986 by cellist [[David Darling (musician)|David Darling]] and flautist [[Bonnie Insull]]. The core of the teaching methods center on [[Humanistic education]].
Graduates of the ''Musicianship and Leadership Program'' facilitate a wide range of music events and programs such as [[drum circle]]s and [[flute circle]]s.
== Philosophy == The philosophy of Music for People is encapsulated in a Bill of Musical Rights that centers on the need for musical self-expression, authenticity, and acceptance of the full range of music traditions and the musical contributions of all people, regardless of their level of experience.<ref name="MBR">{{cite web |url=http://www.MusicForPeople.org/rights.html |title=A Bill of Musical Rights |author=David Darling |date=1997 |work=Music for People |accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref>
The approach to music facilitation is generally unconventional, using a playful teaching style<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.windovertheearth.com/Mdarling.html |title=Wind over the Earth |author=Micky Houlihan |date=1997 |accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref> developed by David Darling beginning with his work leading workshops as part of the [[Paul Winter Consort]] beginning in 1980. The approach to tonal and rhythmic improvisation has been found to have positive social influences, both similar to and contrasting with clinical [[music therapy]] approaches.<ref>{{cite book |author=Kalani Das |title=The Way of Music - Creating Sound Connections in Music Therapy |publisher=Sarsen Publishing |location=Denton, Texas |isbn=978-1-60725-278-8 |edition=First |year=2011 |url=http://kalanimusic.com/products/books/the-way-of-music/}}</ref>
One of the core techniques used is ensemble playing, where participants have varying levels of musical experience, come from different genres of music, and often include instruments that typically do not play together.<ref>{{cite book |author=Lynn Miller |title=SpiritArts - Transformation through Creating Art, Music and Dance |publisher=Expressive Therapy Press |location=Phoenixville, Pennsylvania |isbn=978-0-615-84150-2 |edition=First |year=2013 |page=65 |url=http://spiritarts.us/}}</ref>
Darling's dedication to Arts-in-Education innovation and creativity earned him the 1995 Artist of the Year Award from Young Audiences, Inc.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Houle |first1=Arthur |title=Five Minutes With ... David Darling |journal=The American Music Teacher |date=April 1, 2006}}</ref>
Music for People has prompted many offshoots, such as the Improv Collective at Fredonia University<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fredonia.edu/music/improv/|title=The Improv Collective |author=David Rudge, Ph.D.|date=2011|accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref> and the classical music program at DePauw University that incorporates music improvisation.<ref>{{cite news |title=Making Up the Classics |author=Alexandra Alter |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122781195665062021 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=November 28, 2008 |accessdate=5 January 2012}}</ref>
== A Musical Bill of Rights ==
This sums up the philosophy promoted by the organization:<ref name="MBR" />
* Human beings need to '''express''' themselves daily in a way that invites physical and emotional release. * Musical self-expression is a joyful and healthy means of communication available to absolutely everyone. * There are as many '''different ways''' to make music as there are people. * The human '''voice''' is the most natural and powerful vehicle for musical self-expression. The differences in our voices add richness and depth to music. * Sincerely expressed '''emotion''' is at the root of meaningful musical expression. * Your music is more '''authentically expressed''' when your body is involved in your musical expression. * The European tradition of music is only '''one sound'''. All other cultures and traditions deserve equal attention. * Any combination of people and instruments can '''make music''' together. * There are '''no "unmusical" people''', only those with no musical experience. * Music improvisation is a '''unique''' and '''positive''' way to build skills for life-expression. * In improvisation as in life, we must be responsible for the '''vibrations''' we send one another.
== Resources == The techniques used in music education have been published in a handbook on musical forms and structures,<ref>Oshinsky, 2008</ref> as well as a set of three CDs of interviews with [[David Darling (musician)|David Darling]] and Julie Weber.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.DarlingConversations.com/ |title=The Darling Conversations |author=David Darling |author2=Julie Weber |date=2008 |accessdate=2012-01-05}}</ref>
There are also supplementary information relating to the Musicianship and Leadership program relating to the development of activities in music workshops.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musicforpeople.org/pdf/TenQsJune07.pdf |title=Ten Questions that can be applied to any Music for People Return to Child activity|author=James Oshinsky |date=2007 |accessdate=2012-01-15}}</ref>
== Music Programs, University Courses, and Workshops by Graduates == Here are links to some of the music workshops that have been organized and facilitated by graduates of the Musicianship and Leadership program:
* {{cite web |url=http://www.fredonia.edu/som/improv/ |title=The Improv Collective|author1=David Rudge|accessdate=2012-01-15}} * {{cite web |url=http://improvinsights.files.wordpress.com/2012/01/oshinsky-improv-syllabus1.pdf |title=Improvisation Ensemble |author=James Oshinsky |accessdate=2012-02-23}} Undergraduate course at Adelphi University, Garden City, New York. * {{cite web |url=http://www.rhythmicconnections.com/ |title=Rhythmic Connections|author1=Mary Knysh|accessdate=2012-01-15}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.MusicInTheMoment.com/ |title=Music in the Moment|author=Ron Kravitz |accessdate=2012-01-15}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.FluteHaven.com/ |title=Flute Haven Native Flute School|author1=Clint Goss|author2=Lynn Miller|author3=Eric Miller|author4=Ron Kravitz|accessdate=2012-01-15}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.sounddirections.net/ |title=Sound Directions|author1=Randy Brody|accessdate=2012-01-15}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.music-from-the-heart.com/ |title=Music From The Heart |author=James Oshinsky |accessdate=2012-02-22}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == {{cite book |last1=Oshinsky |first1=James |title=Return to Child - Music for People’s Guide to Improvising Music and Authentic Group Leadership |edition=Second |date=January 2008 |url=http://www.ReturnToChild.com/}}
== External links == * [http://www.MusicForPeople.org/ Music for People: Official web site] *[https://www.musicforpeople.ch Music for People Europe: Web site for European offers] *

The '''National Association of Schools of Art and Design''' ('''NASAD'''), founded in 1944, is an accrediting organization of colleges, schools and universities in the [[United States]]. The organization establishes standards for graduate and undergraduate degrees. Member institutions complete periodic peer review processes to become, and remain, accredited. NASAD accreditation should not be confused with [[regional accreditation]]. ==Standards for accreditation== The National Association for Schools of Art and Design has stringent criteria for accrediting schools. For example, the NASAD requires that schools clearly publish their tuition rates and course descriptions.{{cite web|title=NASAD Handbook 2012-13|url=http://nasad.arts-accredit.org/site/docs/Handbook/NASAD_HANDBOOK_2012-13.pdf|accessdate=9 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327164157/http://nasad.arts-accredit.org/site/docs/Handbook/NASAD_HANDBOOK_2012-13.pdf|archivedate=27 March 2013|df=}} In addition, board members assess the schools' art curricula and promote new standards to advance art education. ==Institutional members== As of January 16, 2016 the National Association of Schools of Art and Design has 367 accredited institutional members:[http://nasad.arts-accredit.org/index.jsp?page=Member%20Lists Member Lists] {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} *[[Academy of Art University]] *[[American Film Institute]]
