{{Infobox university |name = Vilnius University |native_name = Vilniaus universitetas |image_name = Vilnius university logo.svg |image_size = |image_alt = Universitas Vilnensis |caption = |latin_name = universitas Vilnensis |motto = Hinc itur ad astra {{la icon}} |mottoeng = From here the way leads to the stars |established = {{Start date|1579}} |closed = |type = [[Public university|Public]] |affiliation = St. John's Church |endowment = |budget = |officer_in_charge = |chairman = |chancellor = |president = |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = |rector = Artūras Žukauskas |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = |head = |academic_staff = 1,370 (3,662 staff total) |administrative_staff = |students = 20,864 |undergrad = 11,418 |postgrad = 3,560 |doctoral = 860{{cite web |url=http://www.vu.lt/en/about-us/facts-and-figures |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170711183608/http://www.vu.lt/en/about-us/facts-and-figures |archivedate=2017-07-11 |df= }} |other = 794 (MDs in [[Residency (medicine)|residency]])
1224 (international students) |city = [[Vilnius]] |state = |province = |country = [[Lithuania]] |coor = {{Coord|54|40|57|N|25|17|14|E|type:edu|display=title}} |campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] |former_names = ''Academia et Universitas Vilnensis Societatis Jesu'' (1579)
Principal School of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] (1783)
Principal School of Vilnius (1795)
Imperial University of Vilnius (1803)
[[Stephen Bathory]] University (1919)
State University of Vilnius (1944) http://www.vu.lt/site_files/InfS/Leidiniai/Vilnius_University_1579_2004.pdf |free_label = |free = |colors = {{color strip|maroon}} [[Maroon]] |colours = |athletics = |sports = |nickname = |mascot = |affiliations = [[European University Association|EUA]], [[Santander Network]], [[Institutional Network of the Universities from the Capitals of Europe|UNICA]], [[Utrecht Network]] |website = [http://www.vu.lt/ www.vu.lt] |logo = File:Logo vilnius university.svg |footnotes = }} '''Vilnius University''' ({{lang-lt|Vilniaus universitetas}}; [[#Changes of the name|former names exist]]) is the [[List of oldest universities in continuous operation|oldest university]] in the [[Baltic states]] and one of the oldest in [[Northern Europe]]. It is the largest [[university]] in [[List of universities in Lithuania|Lithuania]]. The university was founded in 1579 as the [[Jesuit]] Academy (College) of Vilnius by [[Grand Duke of Lithuania]] and [[King of Poland]], [[Stephen Báthory]]. It was the third oldest university (after the [[Cracow Academy]] and the [[University of Königsberg|Albertina]]) in the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]. In the aftermath of the [[Third Partition of Poland]] (1795) and the [[November Uprising]] (1830–1831), the university was closed down and suspended its operation until 1919. In the [[aftermath of World War I]] the university saw failed attempts to restart it by [[Lithuania]] (December 1918) and invading [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] forces (March 1919). It finally resumed operations as Stefan Batory University in [[Second Polish Republic|Poland]] (August 1919), a period followed by another [[Polish–Soviet War|Soviet occupation]] in 1920, and the less than two-years of the [[Republic of Central Lithuania]], [[Republic of Central Lithuania general election, 1922|incorporated]] into Poland in 1922. Following [[Soviet invasion of Poland]] in September 1939, the university was briefly administered by the Lithuanian authorities (from October 1939), and then after [[Occupation and annexation of the Baltic states by the Soviet Union (1940)|Soviet annexation of Lithuania]] (June 1940), punctuated by a period of German occupation after [[German invasion of the Soviet Union]] (1941–1944), administrated as Vilnius State University by the [[Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic]]. In 1945 the Polish community of [[student]]s and [[scholar]]s of Stefan Batory University was [[Polish population transfers (1944–1946)|transferred]] to [[Nicolaus Copernicus University in Toruń]].{{cite book |title=Dzieje nauki polskiej |last= Iłowiecki |first=Maciej |year=1981 |publisher=Wydawnictwo „Interpress” |location=Warszawa |page=241 |isbn=83-223-1876-6}} After Lithuania regained its independence in 1990, following the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], it resumed its status as one of the prominent universities in Lithuania. The wide-ranging Vilnius University ensemble represents all major architectural styles that predominated in [[Lithuania]]: [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]], [[Renaissance]], [[Baroque]] and [[Classicism]]. ==History== ===Changes of the name=== [[File:GreatCourtyard.jpg|thumb|The Grand Courtyard of Vilnius University and the Church of St. John, [[Jan Kazimierz Wilczyński]], drawing, circa 1850]] The university has been known by many names during its history. Due to its long history of Jewish, Polish and Russian influence or rule, the city portion of its name is rendered as Vilna ([[Latin language|Latin]]), Wilna ([[German language|German]]) or Wilno ([[Polish language|Polish]]), in addition to Lithuanian Vilnius (see [[History of Vilnius]]). * 1579–1782: Alma Academia et Universitas Vilnensis Societatis Iesu.{{cite book|title=Lithuania Today|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I088AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1978|publisher="Gintaras"}} The Latin name is rendered into English as Jesuit Academy, Jesuit College, or Academy of Vilnius (Vilna/Wilna/Wilno).{{cite book|author1=Lola Romanucci-Ross|author2=George A. De Vos|title=Ethnic identity: creation, conflict, and accommodation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZcavoW8-uFMC&pg=PA251|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1995|publisher=Rowman Altamira|isbn=978-0-7619-9111-3|page=251}}{{cite book|author=Czesław Miłosz|title=The history of Polish literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R-MkT9vavwIC&pg=PA114|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1983|publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-04477-7|pages=114–}}{{cite book |author1=Antanas Jusaitis |author2=Lithuanian Catholic Truth Society|title=The history of the Lithuanian nation and its present national aspirations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Xo2AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA74|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1918|publisher=The Lithuanian Catholic Truth Society|pages=74–}}{{cite book|author=Giedrė Mickūnaitė|title=Making a great ruler: Grand Duke Vytautas of Lithuania|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a5zKQM7eEMgC&pg=PA156|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=2006|publisher=Central European University Press|isbn=978-963-7326-58-5|pages=156–}}{{cite book|author=Norman Davies|title=God's Playground: 1795 to the present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EBpghdZeIwAC&pg=PA169|accessdate=9 March 2011|date=May 2005|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-12819-3|pages=169–}}{{cite book|author=Jerzy Jan Lerski|title=Historical dictionary of Poland, 966-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QTUTqE2difgC&pg=PA629|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-26007-0|pages=629–}}{{cite book|author1=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|author2=Centre for Co-operation with Non-members|title=Lithuania|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LD20BC-MfAgC&pg=PA201|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=2002|publisher=OECD Publishing|isbn=978-92-64-18717-7|page=201}}{{cite book|author=Oskar Halecki|title=From Florence to Brest (1439-1596)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nOY7AAAAMAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1958|publisher=Fordham University Press}}{{cite book|author=Oskar Garstein|title=Rome and the Counter-Reformation in Scandinavia: Jesuit educational strategy, 1553-1622|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BCps9VpXdV4C&pg=PA236|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1992|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-09393-5|page=236}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jesuit.lt/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=50&cid=20|publisher=Baltic Jesuit advancement project|title=JESUITS IN LITHUANIA (A SHORT HISTORY)|accessdate=2011-03-09}}{{cite book|author=Hugh Chisholm|title=The Encyclopædia britannica: a dictionary of arts, sciences, literature and general information|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8vstAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA166|accessdate=11 March 2011|year=1911|publisher=The Encyclopædia Britannica Company|page=166}} * 1782–1803: Schola Princeps Magni Ducatus Lithuaniae: Principal School of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]]{{cite book|author=Jonas Kubilius|title=A Short history of Vilnius University|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mkW7AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1979|publisher=Mokslas}} * 1803–1832: Imperatoria Universitas Vilnensis. Rendered into English as Imperial University of Vilnius (Vilna/Wilna/Wilno){{cite book|author=Tomas Venclova|title=Vilnius: city guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1v8iAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=2002|publisher=R. Paknio leidykla|isbn=978-9986-830-48-1}}{{cite book|title=Soviet physics-collection|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JODyAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1979|publisher=Allerton Press.}}{{cite book|author=Miriam A. Drake|title=Encyclopedia of library and information science, second edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b9tdjofCdK4C&pg=PA327|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=2005|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-8493-3894-6|pages=327–}}{{cite book|author=Laimonas Briedis|title=Vilnius: city of strangers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mKcrAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|date=1 March 2009|publisher=CEU Press|isbn=978-963-9776-44-9}}{{cite book|author1=Marcel Cornis-Pope|author2=John Neubauer|title=History of the literary cultures of East-Central Europe: junctures and disjunctures in the 19th and 20th centuries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-0mJ7blUGtQC&pg=PA6|accessdate=9 March 2011|date=15 July 2007|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|isbn=978-90-272-3455-1|pages=6–}} * 1832–1919: Closed, originally by order of Tsar [[Nicholas I of Russia|Nicholas I]]{{cite book|author=David H. Stam|title=International dictionary of library histories|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pf8rV7tUCN8C&pg=PA926|accessdate=10 March 2011|date=1 November 2001|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-57958-244-9|pages=926}} * 1919–1939: Stefan Batory University{{cite book|author1=Sarunas Liekis|author2=Šarūnas Liekis|title=1939: the year that changed everything in Lithuania's history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ST3LrBPOM4gC&pg=PA174|accessdate=9 March 2011|date=1 January 2010|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-420-2762-6|pages=174–175}} (''Uniwersytet Stefana Batorego'' in [[Poland]]) * 1940–1943: Vilnius University (this period encompassed the [[Occupation and annexation of the Baltic states by the Soviet Union (1940)|first Soviet occupation]] and [[Occupation of Lithuania by Nazi Germany|German occupation]]) * 1944–1955: Vilnius State University * 1955–1990: Vilnius State University of [[Vincas Kapsukas]]{{cite book |title=The Current digest of the Soviet Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FzQJAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1955|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies.}} ** 1971–1979: Vilnius [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] State University of Vincas Kapsukas (Vilniaus Darbo raudonosios vėliavos ordino valstybinis Vinco Kapsuko universitetas) ** 1979–1990: Vilnius [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour|Orders of the Red Banner of Labour]] and [[Order of Friendship of Peoples|Friendship of Peoples]] State University of Vincas Kapsukas (Vilniaus Darbo raudonosios vėliavos ir Tautų draugystės ordinų valstybinis V. Kapsuko universitetas) * 1990–present: Vilnius University ===History by period=== ====Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth==== [[File:Bronze door of Vilnius University library.Lithuania.jpg|thumb|left|A bronze door at the Vilnius University Library commemorates the first [[Martynas Mažvydas|Lithuanian book]].]] In 1568, the [[Lithuanian nobility]]{{Cite book|title=Lietuvų kalbos istorija (Senųjų raštų kalba) |last=Zinkevičius |first=Zigmas |authorlink=Zigmas Zinkevičius |year=1988 |pages=159|publisher=Mintis |location=Vilnius |isbn=5-420-00102-0|language=lt}} asked the [[Jesuits]] to create an institution of higher learning either in [[Vilnius]] or [[Kaunas]]. The following year [[Walerian Protasewicz]], the [[List of bishops of Vilnius|bishop of Vilnius]], purchased several buildings in the city center and established the Vilnian Academy (Almae Academia et Universitas Vilnensis Societatis Jesu). Initially, the academy had three divisions: [[trivium (education)|humanities]], [[philosophy]], and [[theology]]. The curriculum at the college and later at the academy was taught in [[Latin language|Latin]].{{Cite book|title=Lietuvų kalbos istorija (Senųjų raštų kalba) |last=Zinkevičius |first=Zigmas |authorlink=Zigmas Zinkevičius |year=1988 |pages=160|publisher=Mintis |location=Vilnius |isbn=5-420-00102-0|language=lt}}{{cite book|author=Kevin O'Connor|title=Culture and customs of the Baltic states |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8Dl2i1Fkd_cC&pg=PA81|accessdate=10 March 2011 |year=2006 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33125-1|pages=81–}} At the beginning of the 17th century there are records about special groups that taught [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]]-speaking students Latin, most probably using [[Konstantinas Sirvydas]]' compiled dictionary.{{Cite book|title=Lietuvų kalbos istorija (Senųjų raštų kalba) |last=Zinkevičius |first=Zigmas |authorlink=Zigmas Zinkevičius |year=1988 |pages=161|publisher=Mintis |location=Vilnius |isbn=5-420-00102-0|language=lt}} The first students were enrolled into the Academy in 1570. A library at the college was established in the same year, and [[Sigismund II Augustus]] donated 2500 books to the new college. In its first year of existence the college enrolled 160 students. On April 1, 1579, [[Stefan Batory]] [[King of Poland]] and [[Grand Duke of Lithuania]], upgraded the academy and granted it equal status with the [[Jagiellonian University|Kraków Academy]], creating the Alma Academia et Universitas Vilnensis Societatis Iesu. His edict was approved by [[Pope]] [[Gregory XIII]]'s [[Papal bull|bull]] of October 30, 1579. The first [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the Academy was [[Piotr Skarga]]. He invited many scientists from various parts of Europe and expanded the library, with the sponsorship of many notable persons: [[Sigismund II Augustus]], Bishop [[Walerian Protasewicz]], and [[Kazimierz Lew Sapieha]]. Lithuanians at the time comprised about one third of the students (in 1568 there were circa 700 students), others were [[Germans]], [[Poles]], [[Swedish people|Swedes]], and even [[Hungarians]]. [[File:Vilnius University Great Courtyard 2, Vilnius, Lithuania - Diliff.jpg|thumb|right|The Grand Courtyard of Vilnius University and [[Church of St. Johns, Vilnius|Church of St. Johns]].]] In 1575, Duke [[Mikołaj Krzysztof Radziwiłł]] and [[Elżbieta Ogińska]] sponsored a printing house for the academy, one of the first in the region. The printing house issued books in [[Latin]] and [[Polish language|Polish]] and the first surviving book in [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] printed in the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] was in 1595. It was ''Kathechismas, arba Mokslas kiekvienam krikščioniui privalus'' authored by [[Mikalojus Daukša]]. The academy's growth continued until the 17th century. The following era, known as [[The Deluge (history)|The Deluge]], led to a dramatic drop in the number of students who matriculated and in the quality of its programs. In the middle of the 18th century, education authorities tried to restore the academy. This led to the foundation of the first [[observatory]] in the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] (the fourth such professional facility in Europe), in 1753, by [[Tomasz Żebrowski]]. The [[Commission of National Education]] ({{lang-pl|Komisja Edukacji Narodowej}}), the world's first ministry of education, took control of the academy in 1773, and transformed it into a modern [[University]]. The language of instruction (as everywhere in the commonwealth's higher education institutions) changed from [[Latin]] to [[Polish language|Polish]].{{cite book|author=Jerzy Jan Lerski|title=Historical dictionary of Poland, 966-1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QTUTqE2difgC&pg=PA74|accessdate=10 March 2011|year=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-313-26007-0|pages=74–}}{{cite book|author1=Marcel Cornis-Pope|author2=John Neubauer|title=History of the literary cultures of East-Central Europe: junctures and disjunctures in the 19th and 20th centuries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5pAwqsSyTlsC&pg=PA19|accessdate=10 March 2011|date=13 September 2006|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|isbn=978-90-272-3453-7|pages=19–}}{{cite book|author1=Ted Tapper|author2=David Palfreyman |title=Understanding mass higher education: comparative perspectives on access|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hd4FT_l2GDYC&pg=PA141|accessdate=10 March 2011|date=23 December 2004|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-415-35491-2|pages=141–}} Thanks to the [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the academy, [[Marcin Poczobutt-Odlanicki]], the academy was granted the status of "Principal School" ({{lang-pl|Szkoła Główna}}) in 1783. The commission, the secular authority governing the academy after the dissolution of the [[Jesuit]] order, drew up a new statute. The school was named Academia et Universitas Vilnensis. ====Partitions==== After the [[Partitions of Poland|Partitions of Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]], [[Vilnius]] was annexed by the [[Russian Empire]]. However, the Commission of National Education retained control over the academy until 1803, when Tsar [[Alexander I of Russia]] accepted the new statute and renamed it The Imperial University of Vilna (Императорскiй Виленскiй Университетъ). The institution was granted the rights to the administration of all education facilities in the former [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]]. Among the notable personae were the curator (governor) [[Adam Jerzy Czartoryski]] and rector [[Jan Śniadecki]]. [[File:Vilnius University, Lithuania, Sept. 2008.jpg|thumb|left|[[Vilnius University Library]] Courtyard]] The university flourished. It used Polish as the instructional language, although [[Russian language|Russian]] was added to the curriculum.{{cite book|author=Piotr Stefan Wandycz|title=The lands of partitioned Poland, 1795-1918|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TVMmGKsbWJ4C&pg=PA95|accessdate=9 March 2011|year=1974|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-95358-8|pages=95–}} It became known for its studies of [[Belarusian culture|Belarusian]] and [[Lithuanian culture]]. By 1823, it was one of the largest in Europe; the student population exceeded that of the [[Oxford University]]. A number of students, among them poet [[Adam Mickiewicz]], were arrested in 1823 for [[conspiracy (political)|conspiracy]] against the tsar (membership in [[Filomaci]]). In 1832, after the [[November Uprising]], the university was closed by Tsar [[Nicholas I of Russia]]. Two of the faculties were turned into separate schools: the Medical and Surgical Academy (''Akademia Medyko-Chirurgiczna'') and the Roman Catholic Academy (''Rzymsko-Katolicka Akademia Duchowna''). But soon they were closed as well with Medical and Surgical Academy transformed into Medical faculty of [[University of Kiev]] (now [[Bogomolets National Medical University]]), and latter one being transformed into [[Saint Petersburg Roman Catholic Theological Academy]] (after the October Revolution of 1917 moved to Poland where it became [[John Paul II Catholic University of Lublin|Catholic University of Lublin]]). The repression that followed the failed uprising included banning the [[Polish language|Polish]] and [[Lithuanian language]]s; all education in those languages was halted. ====1918-1939==== Lithuania declared its independence in February 1918. The university, with the rest of Vilnius and Lithuania, was opened three times between 1918 and 1919. The Lithuanian National Council re-established it in December 1918, with classes to start on January 1, 1919. [[Soviet westward offensive of 1918–1919|An invasion]] by the [[Red Army]] interrupted this plan. A Lithuanian communist, [[Vincas Kapsukas-Mickevičius]], then sponsored a plan to re-open it as "Labor University" in March 1919 in the short-lived [[Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic (1918–1919)|Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic]] (later, [[Lithuanian–Belorussian Soviet Socialist Republic]]), but the city was [[Vilna offensive|taken by Poland]] in April 1919. Marshall [[Józef Piłsudski]] reopened it as [[Stefan Batory]] University (''Uniwersytet Stefana Batorego'') on August 28, 1919. The city would fall to the Soviets again in 1920, who transferred it to the Lithuanian state after their defeat in the [[battle of Warsaw (1920)|battle of Warsaw]]. Finally, in the aftermath of the [[Żeligowski's Mutiny]] and [[Republic of Central Lithuania general election, 1922]], the [[Vilnius Region]] was subsequently annexed by Poland. In response to the dispute over the region, many Lithuanian scholars moved to [[Vytautas Magnus University]] in [[Kaunas]], the interwar capital.{{Cite book|title=FOUR CENTURIES OF ENLIGHTENMENT: A Historic View of the University of Vilnius, 1579-1979|author=[[Tomas Venclova]]|url=http://www.lituanus.org/1981_2/81_2_01.htm |date=Summer 1981 |publisher=[[Lituanus]]|accessdate=2009-01-13}} [[File:VU bibliotekos Smuglevičiaus salė.JPG|thumb|P. Smuglevičius hall in the [[Vilnius University Library]].]] The university quickly recovered and gained international prestige, largely because of the presence of notable scientists such as [[Władysław Tatarkiewicz]], [[Marian Zdziechowski]], and [[Henryk Niewodniczański]]. Among the students of the university at that time was future [[Nobel prize]] winner [[Czesław Miłosz]]. The university grew quickly, thanks to government grants and private donations. Its library contained 600,000 volumes, including historic and cartographic items which are still in its possession. In 1938 the university had: * 7 institutes * 123 professors * 104 scientific units (including two hospitals) * 3110 students The university's international students included 212 [[Russians]], 94 [[Belarusians]], 85 [[Lithuanians]], 28 [[Ukrainians]] and 13 [[Germans]]. Anti-Semitism increased during the 1930s and a system of [[ghetto benches]], in which Jewish students were required to sit in separate areas, was instituted at the university.{{cite book|author=Emanuel Melzer|title=No way out: the politics of Polish Jewry, 1935-1939|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=co3KJikOaBYC&pg=PA75|accessdate=10 March 2011|year=1997|publisher=Hebrew Union College Press|isbn=978-0-87820-418-2|pages=74–76}} Violence erupted; the university was closed for two weeks during January 1937. In February Jewish students were denied entrance to its grounds. The faculty was then authorized to decide on an individual basis whether the segregation should be observed in their classrooms and expel those students who would not comply. 54 Jewish students were expelled but were allowed to return the next day under a compromise in which in addition to Jewish students, Lithuanian, Belarusian, and "Polish democratic" students were to be seated separately. Rector of the university, [[Władysław Marian Jakowicki]], resigned his position in protest over the introduction of the ghetto benches.{{cite book|author=Ludwik Hass |title=Wolnomularze polscy w kraju i na śwíecíe 1821-1999: słownik biograficzny |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r9wqAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=11 March 2011 |year=1999 |publisher=Rytm|isbn=978-83-87893-52-1|page=183}} ====World War II==== Following the [[invasion of Poland]] the university continued its operations. The city was soon [[Soviet invasion of Poland|occupied by the Soviet Union]]. Most of the professors returned after the hostilities ended, and the faculties reopened on October 1, 1939. On October 28, [[Vilnius]] was transferred to [[Lithuania]] which considered the previous eighteen years as an occupation by Poland of its capital.D. Trenin. The End of Eurasia: Russia on the Border Between Geopolitics and Globalization. 2002, p.164 The university was closed on December 15, 1939 by the authorities of the Republic of Lithuania. All the faculty, staff, and its approximately 3,000 students dismissed. Students were ordered to leave the dormitories; 600 ended in a refugee camp. Professors had to leave their university flats. Following the [[Lithuanization]] policies, in its place a new university, named Vilniaus universitetas, was created. Its faculty came from the [[Kaunas University]]. The new charter specified that Vilnius University was to be governed according to the statute of the [[Vytautas Magnus University]] of [[Kaunas]], and that [[Lithuanian language]] programs and faculties would be established. Lithuanian was named as the official language of the university. A new academic term started on 22 January; only 13 of the new students had former Polish citizenship. Polish Law and Social Sciences, Humanities, Medical, Theological, Mathematical-Life sciences faculties continued to [[Education in Poland during World War II|work underground]] with lectures and exams held in private flats until 1944.{{pl icon}} Mikołaj Tarkowski, [http://vebba.pl/ug/wp-content/mikolaj-tarkowski-usb.pdf Wydział Prawa i Nauk Społecznych Uniwersytetu Stefana Batorego w Wilnie 1919-1939, - przyczynek do dziejów szkolnictwa wyższego w dwudziestoleciu międzywojennym] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227040642/http://vebba.pl/ug/wp-content/mikolaj-tarkowski-usb.pdf |date=2008-02-27 }} Polish professors who took part in the underground courses included [[Iwo Jaworski]], [[Kazimierz Petrusewicz]] and [[Bronisław Wróblewski]]. The diplomas of the underground universities were accepted by many [[Poland|Polish]] universities after the war. Soon after the [[Soviet occupation of Baltic states|annexation of Lithuania]] by the Soviet Union, while some Polish professors were allowed to resume teaching, many others (along with some Lithuanian professors) who were deemed "[[reactionary]]" were arrested and sent to prisons and [[gulag]]s in Russia and [[Kazakhstan]]. Between September 1939 and July 1941, the Soviets arrested and deported nineteen Polish faculty and ex-faculty of the University of Stefan Batory, of who nine perished: Professors [[Stanisław Cywinski]], [[Władysław Marian Jakowicki]], [[Jan Kempisty]], [[Józef Marcinkiewicz]], [[Tadeusz Kolaczyński]], [[Piotr Oficjalski]], [[Włodzimierz Godłowski]], [[Konstanty Pietkiewicz]], and [[Konstanty Sokol-Sokolowski]], the last five victims of the [[Katyn massacre]].Adam Redzik, [http://www.gomezurdanez.com/polonia/adamredzikpolishuniversitas.pdf Polish Universities During the Second World War], ''Encuentros de Historia Comparada Hispano-Polaca / Spotkania poświęcone historii porównawczej hiszpańsko-polskiej'' conference, 2004 The city was occupied by Germany in 1941, and all institutions of higher education for Poles were closed. From 1940 until September 1944, under Lithuanian professor and activist [[Mykolas Biržiška]], the University of Vilnius was open for Lithuanian students under supervision of the German occupation authorities.[http://www.vu.lt/site_files/InfS/Leidiniai/Vilnius_University_1579_2004.pdf History] In 1944, many of Polish students took part in [[Operation Ostra Brama]]. The majority of them were later arrested by the [[NKVD]] and suffered repressions from their participation in the [[Armia Krajowa]] resistance. ====Soviet period (1945-1990)==== [[File:2011 0825 Vilnius 55.jpg|thumb|Petras Repšys’ fresco "The Seasons of the Year" (painted in 1976-1984) with motifs from [[Baltic mythology]] at the Centre of Lithuanian Studies.]] Educated Poles were transferred to [[People's Republic of Poland]] after World War II under the guidance of [[State Repatriation Office]]. As the result many of former students and professors of Stefan Batory joined universities in Poland. To keep contact with each other, the professors decided to transfer whole faculties. After 1945, most of the mathematicians, humanists and biologists joined the [[Nicolaus Copernicus University in Toruń]], while a number of the medical faculty formed the core of the newly founded [[Medical University of Gdańsk]]. The [[Toruń]] university is often considered to be the successor to the Polish traditions of the Stefan Batory University. In 1955{{cite web|url=http://www.countries.ru/index.cgi?pid=1397|title=Страны мира|publisher=Countries|accessdate=31 May 2015}} the University was named after [[Vincas Kapsukas]]. After it had been awarded the [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] in 1971 and the [[Order of Friendship of Peoples]] in 1979, its full name until 1990 was Vilnius Order of the Red Banner of Labour and Order of Friendship of Peoples V. Kapsukas State University. Though restrained by the Soviet system, Vilnius University grew and gained significance and developed its own, Lithuanian identity. Vilnius University began to free itself from Soviet ideology in 1988, thanks to the policy of [[glasnost]]. ====After 1990==== On March 11, 1990, [[Lithuania]] declared independence, and the university regained autonomy. Since 1991, Vilnius University has been a signatory to the [[Magna Charta of the European Universities]]. It is a member of the [[European University Association]] (EUA) and the [[Conference of Baltic University Rectors]]. ==Status today== [[File:VU studies start 2009 11.JPG|thumb|right|The Senate of Vilnius University during the celebration of the beginning of the study year]] In modern times, the university still offers studies with an internationally recognized content. There are 3 Bachelor and 16 Master study programs in English. As of 10 October 2017, there were 19768 students attending Vilnius University.{{cite web|url=https://www.vu.lt/en/about-vu/facts-and-figures|title=Facts and Figures|last=|first=|date=|website=|accessdate=9 December 2017}} The current rector is Professor [[Artūras Žukauskas (1956)|Artūras Žukauskas]].{{cite web|url=https://www.vu.lt/en/about-vu/structure/rector-s-office|title=Administration – Vilnius University|last=|first=|date=|website=|accessdate=9 December 2017}} The university, specifically the courtyard, was featured in the American TV series ''[[The Amazing Race 12]]''.[https://books.google.com/books?id=9GmK7Ey8zXMC&pg=PA79 Circumnavigating the Globe: Amazing Race 10 to 14 and Amazing Race K. Sarbievijus Courtyard, Vilnius, Lithuania - Diliff.jpg|thumb|right|Observatory Courtyard]] The old campus of Vilnius University consists of 13 buildings and 13 courtyards.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vu.lt/en/about-vu/maps-and-pictures|title=Maps and Pictures|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=2017-12-09|language=en-gb}} At present the Rector's Office, the Library, the Faculties of Philology, Philosophy, and History are situated there. The largest courtyards are: * P. Skargos (The main) courtyard; * M. K. Sarbievijaus courtyard; * Library courtyard; * Observatory courtyard. Faculties of Physics, Economy, Law, and Communication, as well as Business School, Life Sciences Center, and Scholarly Communication and Information Centre are located in Saulėtekis district. ===Ranking=== {{Infobox world university ranking | QS_W = 401-410 | QS_W_ref = [https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2018 QS World University Rankings 2018] | ARWU_W = 601-700 | ARWU_W_ref = [http://www.shanghairanking.com/ARWU2018Candidates.html ARWU World Top 500 Candidates] | THE_W = 601-800 | THE_W_ref = [https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/vilnius-university World University Rankings 2018] | USNWR_W = 543 | USNWR_W_ref = [https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/vilnius-university-503315 US News Rankings 2018] | Leiden_W = 761 | Leiden_W_ref = [http://www.leidenranking.com/Ranking/University2017 Leiden Rankings 2017] }} Vilnius University is ranked 401-410 among World top universities by 2018 QS World University Rankings. In 2017 QS WU Rankings by Subject, Vilnius University is ranked 201-250 in Linguistics and 251-300 in Physics and Astronomy. In QS rankings of Emerging Europe and Central Asia, Vilnius University is ranked 21.{{Cite news|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/universities/vilnius-university|title=Vilnius University|date=2015-07-16|work=Top Universities|access-date=2017-05-27}} Vilnius University is ranked 601-800 in the world and 291 in Europe by Times Higher Education World University Rankings. ===Projects=== Recent and ongoing projects at Vilnius University include: *"Laser Spectrometer for Testing of Coatings of Crystals and Optical Components in Wide Spectral and Angle Range".[https://archive.is/20070627223727/http://www.lasercenter.vu.lt/projektai.php?numeris=1 Laser Research Center] [[NATO Science for Peace]] programme project. Gefenas (Faculty of Medicine). 2016-2019. ===International relations=== Vilnius University has signed more than 130 bilateral cooperation agreements with universities in 41 countries. Under Erasmus+ programme the university has over 800 agreements with 430 European and 55 agreements with partner country universities for the academic exchanges. University students actively participate in such exchange programmes as ERASMUS+, ERASMUS MUNDUS, ISEP, AEN-MAUI and CREPUQ The University is a signatory of the Magna Charta of European universities and a member of the International Association of Universities, European University Association, the Conference of Baltic University Rectors, the Utrecht Network, UNICA Network, and the Baltic Sea Region University Network. In addition, Vilnius University has been invited to join the Coimbra Group, a network of prestigious European universities, from 1 January 2016. ==Institute of International Relations and Political Science== {{Infobox university |name = Vilnius University Institute of International Relations and Political Science |image_name=IIRPS logo.jpg |image_size=350px |established = 1992 |type = Public |director = prof. dr. [[Ramūnas Vilpišauskas]] |faculty = 66 |students = Around 750 |city = {{Flag icon|LTU}} [[Vilnius]] |country = [[Lithuania]] |website = [http://www.tspmi.vu.lt/en IIRPS]}} '''Institute of International Relations and Political Science, Vilnius University''' or '''IIRPS, VU''' ({{lang-lt|Vilniaus universiteto Tarptautinių santykių ir politikos mokslų institutas}}) ({{coord|54|40|43|N|25|17|3.6|E|type:edu_region:LT|display=inline}}) is a branch of the university which prepares political science and international relations specialists and carries out policy research. This is one of the most prominent social science institutions in Central and Eastern Europe and the [[Baltic sea]] region. IIRPS prepares three degree programs: Bachelor of Political Science, six graduate ([[master's degree]]) programs - [[European Studies]], [[Comparative Politics]], International Relations and Diplomacy, [[Public Policy Analysis]], Politics and Media and Eastern European and Russian Studies (the latter is taught in English),{{Citation|last=|first=|title=Public Administration Education in Lithuania|url=http://www.my-world-guide.com/upload/File/Reports/L/lithuania/Public%20Administration%20Education%20in%20Lithuania.pdf|accessdate=2012-03-22}} and also postgraduate studies. Currently there are more than 750 students studying in IIRPS. As of 2015, 1830 students have defended BA and 1072 masters students have defended their MAs as well, while 51 students defended political science PhD dissertations. The director of the Institute since June 10, 2009 has been professor Ramūnas Vilpišauskas. [[File:VU TSPMI pastatas.JPG|350px|thumbnail|right|Institute of International Relationas and Political Science]] === History === The Institute of International Relations and Political Science (IIRPS) of Vilnius University was established on 7 February 1992 by the agreement between Vilnius University and the [[Supreme Committee for the Liberation of Lithuania]]. It became the first political science research institution in independent Lithuania. Having commenced its activities with a two-year programme in international relations, at present IIRPS VU is a faculty-level core academic unit of Vilnius University, wherein studies in political science on all three levels (bachelor, master and PhD) and scientific research are conducted.{{Citation |last= |first= |title=History of the Institute|url=http://www.epin.org/new/vilnius|accessdate=2012-03-20}} While first focusing mostly on educating the future members of the Lithuanian diplomatic corps, the Institute has gradually enlarged its program to include subjects relevant to public administration, non-governmental and private institutions. ==== Directors ==== The first director of the Institute was lawyer, former judge of the [[Constitutional Court of Lithuania]], professor [[Egidijus Kūris]]. Kūris held this position from 1992 to 1999.{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Interview with the First Director of IIRPS|url=http://iq.lt/kava-su-iq/e-kuris-seimas-konstitucija-nesivadovauja-2/|accessdate=2012-03-20}} From 1999 to June 2009, professor [[Raimundas Lopata]] served as the director of the Institute. Lopata is the member of [[European Humanities University]] International Relations Master's program advisory council, the Association President of Republic of Lithuania and the Kaliningrad Oblast of the Russian Federation, the editor of magazine ''Political Science'', a board member of the journal ''Lithuanian Foreign Policy Review'', Deputy Editor of Lithuanian Political Science Association Board. Current director of the IIRPS is professor Ramūnas Vilpišauskas, who was reelected in 2014. Ramūnas was formerly a President of the Lithuanian Political Science Association (2003-2004), a member of the Board of the Open Society Foundation (2002-2004), a member of the European Union Studies Association (EUSA, USA). For several years he has consulted the Lithuanian Government on the process of accession into the EU, worked as a consultant with the authorities of Georgia, Bosnia and Hercegovina, Azerbaijan on the issues of European integration. A member of the Lithuanian Progress Council (since 2010) and the „Sunset“ Commission (since 2009). [[File:Ramūnas Vilpišauskas TSPMI.jpg|thumbnail|Director of the IIRPS, VU Ramūnas Vilpišauskas]] === Studies === '''Undergraduate studies''' Institute of International Relations and Political Science offers a bachelor's program, which aims to provide general knowledge in political sciences. Political science - broad social science discipline that combines sociology, economics, philosophy and other disciplines elements that deals with society, the state and its domestic and foreign policy. Here the wide variety of methods are applied. '''Master'''{{Citation|last=|first=|title=Admission Requirements for International Students|url=http://www.tspmi.vu.lt/en/admission/master-studies/admission-procedure-master|accessdate=2012-03-21}} '''Eastern European and Russian (EERS) Studies''' At the Institute of International Relations and Political Studies six master programs are being taught. The Eastern European and Russian studies are being taught in English. Eastern and Central Europe (EERS) is one of the most dynamic regions in the world having undergone significant transformation. It is not uncommon for developments in the region to influence behavior of some global actors, such as EU, US and Russia, which on their behalf have a significant role in shaping reality throughout most of the Eastern and Central Europe. EERS Studies include a 1.5-year long programme which provides knowledge and skills enabling to conduct independent analysis and evaluation of developments in EERS countries and in the region as a whole.{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Courses in foreign languages|url=http://www.trs.cr.vu.lt/courses/index.php?content=list&mode=loc&l=12|accessdate=2012-03-20}} Students acquire knowledge about domestic policies of the Eastern European states and Russia: their historic development, political and economic systems, and decision making mechanisms. Furthermore, students analyse foreign policies of above-mentioned states: the processes of interstate cooperation and the specifics of foreign policy. They choose the elective courses on the relevant problems in the regions.{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Description of the EERS programme|url=http://www.tspmi.vu.lt/en/admission/master-studies/eastern-european-and-russian-studies|accessdate=2013-07-11}} '''Doctoral Studies''' Political Science PhD program. This is the highest political science study cycle which prepared doctors in political science, developing the political science in Lithuania. Political Science doctoral include: doctoral studies, baseline studies and preparation of the dissertation. Since 1992, 51 students were awarded the PhD degree at the Institute (June 2015). === Departments and centres === The structure of the institute is composed of 3 departments and 3 centres, namely: *Department of [[European Studies]].{{Citation|last=|first=|title=Ramūnas Vilpišauskas, "EUROPEAN STUDIES IN LITHUANIA: SHORT-LASTING FASHION OR PROMISE UNFULFILLED?"|url=http://archive.minfolit.lt/arch/17501/17958.pdf|accessdate=2012-03-22}} Head of the department is prof. dr. Gediminas Vitkus. *Department of [[International Relations]]. Head of the department is prof. dr. Tomas Janeliūnas. *Department of [[Political Theory]]. Head of the Department is prof. dr. Alvydas Jokubaitis. *Centre of [[Public Administration]] and [[Policy Analysis]]. Head of the Center is prof. Vitalis Nakrošis. *Centre of Russian and Central Eastern European Studies Centre.{{Citation|last=|first=|title=Laurynas Jonavicius, Vilnius University, Institute of International Relations and Political Science, WHY UKRAINE AND GEORGIA HAVE NOT USED THE "WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY"?..|url=http://redalyc.uaemex.mx/redalyc/pdf/767/76711407002.pdf/|accessdate=2012-03-22}} Members: prof. Dovile Jakniunaite (head of the centre); prof. [[Natalija Arlauskaitė]]; Dr. Nerijus Maliukevičius; Assoc. prof. Vladas Sirutavičius; Assoc. prof. Inga Vinogradnaitė; prof. Ramūnas Vilpišauskas. *Centre of Nordic Europe Studies. The head of the centre is Assoc. prof. Liutauras Gudžinskas. === Research === [[File:VU TSPMI.jpg|350px|thumbnail]] In cooperation with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Military Academy and other partners, IIRPS conducts research in the area of domestic policy, governance, international relations, foreign policy and diplomacy of both Lithuania and other countries. The Institute organizes international annual conferences and guest lectures. Recently, IIRPS has taken part in co-hosting Baltic Development Forum, which included such prominent guests as President of EC [[Jose Manuel Barroso]], Deputy Director of WTO [[Rufus H. Yerxa]]. Institute's guests included such figures as NATO General Secretary [[A. F. Rasmussen]] and OSCE Secretary General [[Marc Perrin de Brichambaut]]. ==== Projects ==== Some of the projects the Institute has successfully participated in: *'''Russia and the Wider East Central Europe: A Fundamentally Transformed Relationship'''. The overall goal of the project is to facilitate dialogue and mutual understanding between Russia and East Central European (ECE) countries in addressing bilateral and regional issues of common interest and concern. The project applies an extended rather than a narrow definition of the region and seeks to address relations of Russia with the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Romania and Slovakia. IIRPS was given a grant by the [[Friedrich Ebert Foundation]]. *'''Russia's search for identity and political practice, 1990-2010'''. The goal of the project is to analyse the variety and rivalry of identity discourses in the new Russian state in 1990–2010 and to reveal how this constant conceptualization is manifesting itself through political practices and contributes to the formation of the contemporary politics. Instead of unitary depiction of Russia (e.g. as “new empire”, “post-totalitarian state”) the project seeks to demonstrate how different actors participate in the process of Russia's identity representation and how different ways and means are used in creating these representations, thus showing the inconsistencies, breaks and variety of the newly created and modified identity discourses.The discourses of the government (power) and specialised/expert discourses which have certain relationship to power or are cooperating with it (media, the community of historians, cinema, academic, legal discourses) are analysed. ==== Publications ==== Apart from scientific papers prepared by IIRPS VU scientists the Institute issues periodicals wherein results of scientific research are published. *“Politologija”. The quarterly journal devoted to political science published since 1999. *[[Lithuanian Annual Strategic Review]]. Published in cooperation with the Lithuanian Military Academy of General Jonas Žemaitis. The goal of the paper is a complex and permanent analysis and summation of the essential changes taking place on the international, systemic, regional and national planes, which are important to the Lithuanian national security. *[[Lithuanian Foreign Policy Review]]. Published in English in cooperation with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Lithuania in English since 1998. *[[Lithuanian Political Science Yearbook]]. IIRPS VU issues the yearbook of Lithuanian political science wherein articles of Lithuanian politologists devoted to the policy theory, public administration, international policy and other topics are published. *Post Scriptum. Newspaper “Post Scriptum” issued by the IIRPS VU student corporation “RePublica” twice a year wherein students make an attempt to go deeper into important public phenomena, try to assess various social processes in an analytical way, seek the meeting grounds for the attitude towards the underlying problems shaped by different academic subjects. ===People=== The Institute's scientists are known to the public as experts. To name a few, the list would include: * assoc. prof. [[Alvidas Lukošaitis]] * prof. Dr. [[Vitalis Nakrošis]]{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Vitalis Nakrošis, Žilvinas Martinaitis, |quote= "The Lithuanian Public Sector Organisations: The EU-Driven Expansion within the Domestic Arrangements of Autonomy and Control"|url=http://internet.ktu.lt/lt/mokslas/zurnalai/vpa/z29/18-27.pdf|accessdate=2012-03-22}} * prof. dr. [[Natalia Arlauskaite]], * prof emeritus Evaldas Nekrašas, member of the [[Lithuanian Academy of Sciences]] * prof. dr. Ainė Ramonaitė * prof. dr. Alvydas Jokubaitis * assoc. prof. Nerija Putinaitė, former vice-minister of the [[Ministry of Education and Science (Lithuania)|Lithuanian Ministry of Education and Science]] Notable alumni include: * [[Colonel]] to the Military Academy of Lithuania [[Gintaras Bagdonas]] * the Lithuanian Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to Spain [[Audra Plepytė]] * the Lithuanian Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary for the United States and Mexico dr. [[Žygimantas Pavilionis]] In 2015 the Alumni Association was established at the IIRPS, VU with an aim to assist students and help them to adequately prepare to enter the professional life and the career. ===Student organizations=== ====IIRPS student corporation "RePublica"==== [[File:RePublica Logo.png|200px|frameless|right]] [[File:Post scriptum logo.png|200px|frameless|left]] Corporation RePublica is an independent, non-political, public organisation uniting present IIRPS students and its graduates. Founded in 2011, RePublica is the oldest in the institute among the students' organisations. The colors of the corporation are gold, black, red, and the slogan is "Loyalty! Knowledge! Nobility!" The corporation consists of junior, seniors, and philistines. RePublica publishes a thematic newspaper ''Post Scriptum'', organizes conferences, seminars, meetings and public events.{{Citation |last= |first= |title=Student Corporation "RePublica"|url=http://www.republica.lt/en|accessdate=2012-03-21}} Established in 2002, ''Post Scriptum'' is published twice a year and distributed free of charge. ====Scientific Students' Society==== [[File:VU TSPMI SMD.png|100px|frameless|left]] Students' Scientific Society (SSS) was established in 2003. This organization brings together IIRPS students interested in science. Members of the Society organise research projects, meetings with politicians and scientists, lectures of guest speakers, student and international conferences, discussions and seminars, summer expeditions and other events. ====Student's Representation==== [[File:VU SA TSPMI.jpg|140px|frameless|left]] IIRPS SR represents the interests of the students, consolidates student community, and develops closer links with the administration of the Institute. The Student Representative organizes student events, carries out a mentoring program, liaises with other faculties of Student Councils, organizes summer camps for future freshmen. founded in 20003, the Student Representative of IIRPS is one of the youngest in Vilnius University. Along with 13 other agencies, it is part of the Vilnius University Students' Council (VU SC). ==People== ===Nobel Prize winners=== * [[Czesław Miłosz]], poet, The Nobel Prize in Literature 1980 ===Notable professors and alumni of Vilnius University=== [[File:Adam Mickiewicz.PNG|thumb|[[Adam Mickiewicz]], considered one of the greatest Polish and European poets]] ::''in alphabetical order'' revision.text:
"'''Advice, like youth, probably just wasted on the young'''", commonly known by the title "'''Wear Sunscreen'''",{{cite web|last=Alvarez|first=Justin|title="Wear Sunscreen": The Story Behind the Commencement Speech That Kurt Vonnegut Never Gave|url=http://www.openculture.com/2013/11/wear-sunscreen-the-story-behind-the-commencement-speech-that-kurt-vonnegut-never-wrote.html|publisher=Open Culture|accessdate=31 January 2014}} is an [[essay]] written as a hypothetical [[commencement speech]] by [[Column (periodical)|columnist]] [[Mary Schmich]], originally published in June 1997 in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/columnists/chi-schmich-sunscreen-column-column.html|title=Advice, like youth, probably just wasted on the young|first=Chicago|last=Tribune|publisher=}} The essay, giving various pieces of advice on how to live a happier life and avoid common frustrations, spread massively via [[viral email]], often erroneously described as a commencement speech given by author [[Kurt Vonnegut]] at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]. The essay became the basis for a successful [[spoken word]] song released in 1999 by [[Baz Luhrmann]], "'''Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)'''", also known as "'''The Sunscreen Song'''"."The Sunscreen Song (class of '99)" is used as an alternative title on [[:File:Everybody'sfreetowearsunscreen.jpg|the cover of the single]]; see also [https://www.amazon.com/Everybodys-Free-Quindon-Tarver/dp/B00000JHTT#productDescription the single's "Editorial Reviews" on Amazon], and [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/features/daily/march99/sunscreen0318.htm "The Cyber-Saga of the 'Sunscreen' Song"] by the ''Washington Post''. The song inspired numerous [[Parody|parodies]]. ==''Chicago Tribune'' column== [[Mary Schmich]]'s [[Column (periodical)|column]] "Advice, like youth, probably just wasted on the young" was published in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' on June 1, 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/columnists/chi-schmich-sunscreen-column,0,4054576.column |title=Original published article |publisher=Chicago Tribune |author=Mary Schmich |date=1997-06-01}} In the column's introduction Schmich presents the essay as the [[commencement speech]] she would give if she were asked to give one. In the speech she insistently recommends the wearing of [[sunscreen]], and dispenses other advice and warnings which are intended to help people live a happier life and avoid common frustrations. She later explained that the initial inspiration for what advice to offer came from seeing a young woman [[sunbathing]], and hoping that she was wearing sunscreen, unlike what she herself did at that age.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/features/daily/march99/sunscreen0318.htm |title=The Cyber-Saga of the 'Sunscreen' Song |publisher=Washington Post |author=Frank Ahrens |date=1999-03-18}} The essay soon became the subject of an [[urban legend]] which claimed it was an [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] commencement speech given by author [[Kurt Vonnegut]]. In reality, MIT's commencement speaker in 1997 was [[Kofi Annan]] and Vonnegut had never been a commencement speaker there. Despite a follow-up article by Schmich on August 3, 1997,{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-08-03/news/9708030176_1_mr-vonnegut-sunscreen-speech-speech-one-friday-afternoon |title=Follow-up article |publisher=Chicago Tribune |author=Mary Schmich |date=1997-08-03}} the story became so widespread that Vonnegut's lawyer began receiving requests to reprint the speech. Vonnegut commented that he would have been proud had the words been his.{{Citation | last=Fisher | first=Ian | title=It's All the Talk of the Internet's Gossip Underground | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=1997-08-06 | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F04E2D71F3DF935A3575BC0A961958260&sec=technology&spon=&pagewanted=all }} Schmich published a short gift book adaptation of the essay, ''Wear Sunscreen: A Primer for Real Life'', in 1998. A tenth anniversary edition was published in 2008.{{cite book |title = Wear Sunscreen: A Primer for Real Life |first = Mary |last = Schmich |year = 2008 |publisher = Andrews McMeel Publishing |quote = March 1, 2008 [...] The 10th anniversary edition of Mary Schmich's timeless advice [...] |isbn= 0740777173 }} ==Baz Luhrmann version== {{Infobox song | name = Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen) | cover = Everybody'sfreetowearsunscreen.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Baz Luhrmann]] | album = [[Something for Everybody (Baz Luhrmann album)|Something for Everybody]] | B-side = Love Is in the Air | released = 1997 | format = [[CD single|CD]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Spoken word]], [[downtempo]] | length = 7:10 (album)
5:05 (radio) | label = [[EMI]] | writer = [[Mary Schmich]], Nigel Swanston, Tim Cox | producer = Baz Luhrmann, Josh Abrahams, Nellee Hooper | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The essay was used in its entirety by Australian film director [[Baz Luhrmann]] on his 1998 album ''[[Something for Everybody (Baz Luhrmann album)|Something for Everybody]]'', as "Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)". It was released in some territories in 1997, with the speech (including its opening words, "Ladies and Gentlemen of the Class of '97") completely intact. This version appeared in the [[Triple J Hottest 100]] of that year at number 16 in the countdown, and was released on the [[Triple J Hottest 100, 1997|subsequent CD]] in early 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/hottest100_08/history/1997.htm|title=history - triple j hottest 100 - 2008 - triple j|date=26 December 2008|publisher=}} Also known as "The Sunscreen Song", it sampled Luhrmann's remixed version of the song "[[Everybody's Free (To Feel Good)]]" by [[Rozalla]], and opened with the words, "Ladies and Gentlemen of the Class of '99" (instead of "'97", as in the original column). It was later released as a [[Single (music)|single]] in 1999. Luhrmann explained that Anton Monsted, [[Puretone|Josh Abrahams]], and he were working on the remix when Monsted received an email with the supposed Vonnegut speech. They decided to use it but were doubtful of getting through to Vonnegut for permission before their deadline, which was only one or two days away. While searching the Internet for contact information they came upon the "Sunscreen" authorship controversy and discovered that Schmich was the actual author. They emailed her and, with her permission, recorded the song the next day.{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodandvine.com/bazluhrmann/main.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20021205041240/http://hollywoodandvine.com/bazluhrmann/main.html |title=Something for Everybody |publisher=Something for Everybody |date=2002-12-05 | archivedate = 2002-12-05 |accessdate=2009-07-14}} The song features a spoken-word track set over a mellow backing track. The "Wear Sunscreen" speech is narrated by Australian voice actor [[Lee Perry (voice actor)|Lee Perry]].{{cite web|url=http://imdb.com/name/nm1043022/ |title=Lee Perry (I) |publisher=Imdb.com |date=1959-12-16 |accessdate=2009-07-14}} The backing is the choral version of "Everybody's Free (To Feel Good)", a 1991 song by [[Rozalla]], used in Luhrmann's film ''[[William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet]]''. The chorus, also from "Everybody's Free", is sung by [[Quindon Tarver]]. The song was a top ten hit across Europe, but largely obscure in the US until Aaron Scofield, a producer in Phoenix, Arizona, edited the original 12" version into a segment of a syndicated radio show called ''Modern Mix''. This show played on many stations in the United States. In Portland, Oregon—where ''Modern Mix'' played on KNRK—listeners began requesting the track. KNRK program director Mark Hamilton edited the song for time and began playing it regularly. He distributed the song to other program directors that he networked with and the song exploded in the US.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SQ0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA84 |title=Baz Luhrmann Goes to the Top of the Class By Applying His Sunscreen |publisher=Billboard Magazine |date=1999-04-03| accessdate=2016-02-24}} The song reached number 24 on the [[Billboard Hot 100 Airplay]] in the United States; by the time it was released as a commercial single in the country, radio airplay had declined significantly, and only managed to peak at number 45 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]]. It also peaked at number one in the United Kingdom and Ireland, partly due to a media campaign by [[BBC Radio 1|Radio One]] DJ [[Chris Moyles]]. There are four versions of the song: the original 7:09 minute mix from the album ''Baz Luhrmann Presents: Something for Everybody''; a 1999 single release which features a 5:05 minute edit that lacks both choruses; "Geographic's Factor 15+ Mix" that runs for 4:42 minutes; and a "2007 Mix" of the original 7:09 minute version released on the 10th Anniversary Edition of the ''William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet'' soundtrack on which the opening words are changed to "Ladies and gentlemen of the class of 2007". There are two videos for the song: one which uses the 1999 5:05 minute single edit of the song (the version in which [[Quindon Tarver]] is not featured), directed and animated by [[Bill Barminski]]; and another using the 7:09 minute edit made by the Brazilian advertising agency DM9DDB.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xfq_A8nXMsQ|title=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen) Bill Barminski's version|publisher=youtube|date=2007-05-24|accessdate=2010-06-01}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xfq_A8nXMsQ|title=Everybody's Free to Wear Sunscreen! DM9DDB's version|publisher=youtube|date=2006-12-12|accessdate=2010-06-01}} The song also appeared in Germany and was soon followed by a German version with the title "Sonnencreme".{{cite web|url=http://www.sunscreen.de/ | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20010122045300/http://www.sunscreen.de/ |title=everybody's free (to wear sunscreen) |publisher=Brainfusion |date=2001-01-22 | archivedate = 2001-01-22 |accessdate=2009-07-14}} The German translation is narrated by the German actor Dieter Brandecker.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00004WPV2 |title=Sonnencreme (Everybody's...) [Import]: Baz Luhrmann: Amazon.com |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-13}} A Brazilian version is narrated in Portuguese by [[Pedro Bial]], and a Swedish version is narrated by [[Rikard Wolff]]. A Russian adaptation of the song, recorded live by [[Silver Rain Radio]], was performed by Alex Dubas and Yolka.{{cite web|url=http://alex-dubas.livejournal.com/90854.html |script-title=ru:О пользе солнцезащитных кремов |language=Russian |publisher=Blog of Alex Dubas |date=2009-12-20 |accessdate=2011-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811075358/http://alex-dubas.livejournal.com/90854.html |archivedate=2011-08-11 |df= }} On August 10, 2008 the song re-entered the [[UK Singles Chart]] at number 72. ===Track listing=== CD-Maxi Capitol 8871762 (EMI) / EAN 0724388717625{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://www.australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Baz+Luhrmann&titel=Everybody%27s+Free+%28To+Wear+Sunscreen%29&cat=s |title=Baz Luhrmann - Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen) |publisher=australian-charts.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-01}} # "Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)" (Edit) – 5:05 # "Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)" (Geographic's Factor 15+ Mix) – 4:42 # "Love Is in the Air" (Fran Mix) performed by John Paul Young – 4:30 === Charts and certifications === {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ==== Weekly charts ==== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" !scope="col"| Chart (1998–99) !scope="col"| Peak
position |- !scope="row"|Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988–2010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. Martha, VIC, Australia}} | 65 |- !scope="row"{{singlechart|Flanders|31|artist=Baz Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} |- Sunscreen)|accessdate=July 2, 2018}} |- !scope="row"{{singlechart|Dutch40|29|artist=Baz Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen) – The Sunscreen Song (Class of '99)|week=29|year=1999|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} |- !scope="row"{{singlechart|Dutch100|26|artist=Baz Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)|accessdate=July 2, 2018}} |- 2018}} |- !scope="row"{{singlechart|Sweden|15|artist=Baz Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} |- !scope="row"{{singlechart|Switzerland|36|artist=Baz Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} |- !scope="row"{{singlechart|UK|1|artist=Baz Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen) – The Sunscreen Song (Class Luhrmann|song=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} |} {{col-2}} ====Year-end charts==== {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" !scope="col"|Chart (1999) !scope="col"|Position |- !scope="row"|Canada Top Singles (''RPM''){{cite web|url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/image.aspx?Image=nlc008388.9952&URLjpg=http%3a%2f%2fwww.collectionscanada.gc.ca%2fobj%2f028020%2ff4%2fnlc008388.9952.gif&Ecopy=nlc008388.9952|title=RPM 1999 Top 100 Hit Tracks|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|publisher=[[Library and Archives Canada]]|accessdate=July 2, 2018}} |66 |- !scope="row"|Canada Adult Contemporary (''RPM''){{cite web|url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/image.aspx?Image=nlc008388.9964&URLjpg=http%3a%2f%2fwww.collectionscanada.gc.ca%2fobj%2f028020%2ff4%2fnlc008388.9964.gif&Ecopy=nlc008388.9964|title=RPM 1999 Top 100 Adult Contemporary|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|publisher=[[Library and Archives Canada]]|accessdate=July 2, 2018}} |36 |} ==== Certifications ==== {{Certification Table Top}} {{Certification Table Entry|region=United Kingdom|title=Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)|artist=Baz Luhrmann|type=single|award=Gold|accessdate=May 6, 2012|relyear=1999|autocat=yes}} {{Certification Table Bottom|nosales=yes|nounspecified=yes}} {{col-end}} ==Mau Kilauea's Tropical Remix version== {{Infobox song | name = Baz Luhrmann - Wear Sunscreen (Mau Kilauea's Tropical Remix) | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Mau Kilauea]] | album = | released = December 13, 2014 | format = Digital | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = Spoken Word / Minimal House | length = 6:48 | label = [[Spinnin' Records]] | writer = [[Mary Schmich]], Nigel Swanston, Tim Cox, Mau Kilauea | producer = Baz Luhrmann, Josh Abrahams, Nellee Hooper | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} This version was released as a remix to Baz Luhrmann's 1999 version. The remix was written by Mau Kilauea and dubbed as a "Tropical Remix" because of the choice of instrumentation. The song was posted to Soundcloud on Mau Kilauea's page and reposted by Spinnin' Records. The song became a first hit for Mau Kilauea.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} ==Parodies== The Baz Luhrmann song version inspired numerous [[Parody|parodies]]. [[John Safran]] released a song entitled "Not the Sunscreen Song" which peaked at #20 in Australia.{{cite web|author=Steffen Hung |url=http://www.australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=John+Safran&titel=Not+The+Sunscreen+Song&cat=s |title=John Safran - Not The Sunscreen Song |publisher=australian-charts.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-01}} American comedian [[Chris Rock]] enjoyed great success with his spoken word song "[[No Sex (In the Champagne Room)]]" which was in turn parodied on ''[[Mad TV]]'' as "Ain't No Blacks on the TV Screen" in the style of Rock's stand-up. The song was also parodied in an episode of ''[[Disney's House of Mouse]]'' performed by [[Jiminy Cricket]]. The comedy group [[Three Dead Trolls in a Baggie]] also made a parody entitled "The Sunscreen Marketing Board". [[Jegsy Dodd]] and the Original Sinners' version, "Grumpy Old Men", was voted favourite track of 2005 by BBC Radio 1 listeners in their annual [[Festive 50]] poll. [[Angelos Epithemiou]]'s live tour included a parody of the song titled "Don't Muck About". A parody entitled "Mow Against The Grain" appears on the [[King of the Hill (soundtrack)|''King of the Hill'' soundtrack album]]. Another parody by comedian Simmi Areff was played on South African radio station [[East Coast Radio (South Africa)|East Coast Radio]] at the conclusion of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. Another parody was created in 1999 by London Capital Radio Breakfast Show host Chris Tarrant, who created a version called "wear slippers" which consisted of him reading an alternative version of the sunscreen lyrics and demonstrated his disdain for Baz Luhrmann's version. ==Bibliography== *''Wear Sunscreen'' (Andrews McMeel Publishing, 1998) {{ISBN|0-8362-5528-3}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Baz Luhrmann}} [[Category:1998 songs]] [[Category:Australian pop songs]] [[Category:Novelty songs]] [[Category:Personal life]] [[Category:Spoken word]] [[Category:1997 essays]] [[Category:1999 singles]] [[Category:Debut singles]] [[Category:Irish Singles Chart number-one singles|Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)]] [[Category:Number-one singles in Scotland|Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)]] [[Category:UK Singles Chart number-one singles|Everybody's Free (To Wear Sunscreen)]] [[Category:Works originally published in the Chicago Tribune]] [[Category:Songs written by Nigel Swanston]] [[Category:Graduation]]

revision.comment: Changed instance of World Champion of Public Speaking to World Championship of Public Speaking, as this is the correct and official title. Working on moving the page to World Championship of Public Speaking, as the current page title is inaccurate. Also deleted a sentence that stated this contest is referred to by various alternate titles and listed World Championship of Publish Speaking as one of those titles. This was wrong, as World Championship of Public Speaking is the only correct title.
revision.text:
[[File:Toastmasters World Championship Trophy.jpg|right|350px|2002 Toastmasters World Championship Trophy]] '''The World Championship of Public Speaking''' is an annual prize in public speaking given to the winner of an international competition sponsored by [[Toastmasters International]].
== History == The competition, which began in 1938, is said to be the largest speaking contest in the world, with 30,000 participants in 141 countries in 2018.<ref name="SpeechContest"/> In its early decades, it was referred to as the Toastmasters Speech Contest.<ref name="ToastmastersContest">{{cite news |title=Toastmasters Speech Contest Begins in Boston Tomorrow (A 1) |url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/845465194/AFD11DCBC111413APQ/8?accountid=10226 |accessdate=12 June 2018 |publisher=Boston Globe |date=23 March 1958}}</ref> By the 1990s, there were about 10,000 participants every year.<ref name="SantosChampionship">{{cite news |last1=Santos |first1=Jenny Delos |title=Hawaii News Maui orator gets set to enter Toastmasters championship |url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/06/23/hawaii-news/maui-orator-gets-set-to-enter-toastmasters-championship/ |accessdate=12 June 2018 |publisher=[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]] |date=23 June 2017}}</ref> The contest's popularity grew rapidly in the 2000s.<ref name="BlakeHow">{{cite news |last1=Blake |first1=John |title=Stop texting and start speaking: The Olympians of storytelling show you how |url=https://www.cnn.com/2016/10/14/us/toastmasters-champions/index.html |accessdate=12 June 2018 |publisher=CNN |date=14 October 2016}}</ref>
2014 champion Dananjaya Hettiarachchi was the first Asian to win the championship.<ref name="Bahrain">{{cite news |title=WORLD CHAMPION OF PUBLIC SPEAKING TO VISIT BAHRAIN |url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/1615139200/fulltext/2EFA1994EDD04F56PQ/2?accountid=10226 |accessdate=12 June 2018 |publisher=Daily Tribune |date=22 October 2014}}</ref>
== Contest ==
In 2017 competitions who 30,000 contestants from 142 countries entered the competition; the final round was held in Vancouver, Canada.<ref name="MooneyChampion">{{cite news |last1=Mooney |first1=Harrison |title=Vancouver lends an ear to world's best speakers; Toastmasters holds 86th convention, crowns new international champion |url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/1933063679/560D9E99A7AF4294PQ/47?accountid=10226 |accessdate=11 June 2018 |publisher=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=28 August 2017}}</ref> In 2014, the contest drew 33,000 entrants.<ref name="NasirWords">{{cite news |last1=Nasir |first1=Noorain |title=Winning with Words |url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/dananjaya-hettiarachchi-speaks-on/article6535348.ece |accessdate=11 June 2018 |publisher=The Hindu |date=26 October 2014}}</ref>
Contestants give speeches 5 – 7 minutes in length, advancing through club, area, division and district competitions to the championship contest, which has been held in cities in several different countries.<ref name="SpeechContest">{{cite news |title=Resident of France is semifinalist in the world’s largest speech contest |url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/lifestyle/news-and-pr/1477097/resident-of-france-is-semifinalist-in-the-worlds-largest-speech-contest |accessdate=12 June 2018 |publisher=Bangkok Post |date=1 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="HampelClubs">{{cite journal |last1=Hampel |first1=Amir |title=Equal Temperament: Autonomy and Identity in Chinese Public Speaking Clubs |journal=Ethos |date=5 December 2017 |url=https://anthrosource.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/etho.12182 |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
== List of Champions<ref>{{Cite web|url==https://www.toastmasters.org/events/world-championship-of-public-speaking|title=Toastmasters International -World Championship of Public Speaking|website=www.toastmasters.org|language=en|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref> = {| class="wikitable" |'''Year''' |'''Recipient''' |'''From''' |- |2018 |Ramona Smith |Houston, Texas |- |2017 |Manoj Vasudevan |Singapore |- |2016 |Darren Tay |Singapore |- |2015 |Mohammed Qahtani |Dhahran, Saudi Arabia |- |2014 |Dananjaya Hettiarachchi |Nawala Rajagiriya, Sri Lanka |- |2013 |Presiyan Vasilev |Chicago, Illinois |- |2012 |Ryan Avery |Portland, Oregon |- |2011 |Jock Elliott |Bongaree, QLD, Australia |- |2010 |David Henderson |San Antonio, Texas |- |2009 |Mark Hunter |Albany Creek, QLD, Australia |- |2008 |LaShunda Rundles |Dallas, Texas |- |2007 |Vikas Jhingran |Cambridge, Massachusetts |- |2006 |Edward Hearn |Chicago, Illinois |- |2005 |Lance Miller |Glendale, California |- |2004 |Randy Harvey |Sherwood, Oregon |- |2003 |Jim Key |Rowlett, Texas |- |2002 |Dwayne Smith |Decatur, Georgia |- |2001 |Darren LaCroix |Auburn, Massachusetts |- |2000 |Ed Tate |Aurora, Colorado |- |1999 |Craig Valentine |Ellicott City, Maryland |- |1998 |Brett Rutledge |Auckland, New Zealand |- |1997 |Willie Jones |Honolulu, Hawaii |- |1996 |David Nottage |Auckland, New Zealand |- |1995 |Mark Brown |Mount Vernon, New York |- |1994 |Morgan McArthur |Idaho Falls, Idaho |- |1993 |Otis Williams Jr. |Cincinnati, Ohio |- |1992 |Dana LaMon |Lancaster, California |- |1991 |David Ross |Norman, Oklahoma |- |1990 |David Brooks |Austin, Texas |- |1989 |Don Johnson |Torrance, California |- |1988 |Jerry Starke |Milwaukee, Wisconsin |- |1987 |Harold Patterson |Oklahoma City, Oklahoma |- |1986 |M. ==Impact== According to [[CNN]], the contest grew as individuals and corporations worldwide encouraged employees to improve their skill at public speaking.<ref name="BlakeHow"/>
Winners and finalists "snag lucrative gigs on the corporate speaking circuit," becoming full-time professional speakers, speaking coaches, and paid speaking consultants, and they sell books and DVDs to fans.<ref name="BlakeHow"/>
